    Development of Benzenesulfonamide Derivatives as Potent Glutathione Transferase Omega-1 Inhibitors

    • Yiyue Xie
      Yiyue Xie

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Glutathione transferase omega-1 (GSTO1-1) is an enzyme whose function supports the activation of interleukin (IL)-1β and IL-18 that are implicated in a variety of inflammatory disease states for which small-molecule inhibitors are sought. The potent reactivity of the active-site cysteine has resulted in reported inhibitors that act by covalent labeling. In this study, structure–activity relationship (SAR) elaboration of the reported GSTO1-1 inhibitor C1-27 was undertaken. Compounds were evaluated for inhibitory activity toward purified recombinant GSTO1-1 and for indicators of target engagement in cell-based assays. As covalent inhibitors, the kinact/KI values of selected compounds were determined, as well as in vivo pharmacokinetics analysis. Cocrystal structures of key novel compounds in complex with GSTO1-1 were also solved. This study represents the first application of a biochemical assay for GSTO1-1 to determine kinact/KI values for tested inhibitors and the most extensive set of cell-based data for a GSTO1-1 inhibitor SAR series reported to date. Our research culminated in the discovery of 25, which we propose as the preferred biochemical tool to interrogate cellular responses to GSTO1-1 inhibition.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Glutathione (GSH) transferase omega-1 (GSTO1-1) is a member of the omega class of cytosolic glutathione transferases (GSTs). Omega-class GSTs share an atypical cysteine active-site residue and have been found to have broad activities that include dehydroascorbate reductase, monomethylarsonate reductase, and thioltransferase activity, rather than the typical glutathione transferase activity exhibited by most other GSTs. GSTO1-1 alone displays S-(phenacyl)glutathione reductase and deglutathionylase activities.(1)
    GSTO1-1 was recently reported to play a key role in the Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)-mediated proinflammatory pathway.(2) When GSTO1-1 was inhibited, inflammatory responses stimulated by lipopolysaccharide (LPS) are suppressed, including the production of mature interleukin-1β (IL-1β), interleukin-6, and the tumor necrosis factor, the release of reactive oxygen species, and the suppression of antioxidant enzymes. Recently, GSTO1-1 was also identified as a novel NLRP3 inflammasome regulator, functioning by deglutathionylating NEK7, a recently identified component of the NLRP3 inflammasome.(3) By inhibiting GSTO1-1, the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome and the maturation of IL-1β and IL-18 can be suppressed. Thus, inflammatory conditions with pathology resulting from activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome including sepsis, colitis, obesity, diabetes mellitus type 2, Alzheimer’s disease, and acute myocardial infarction(4−7) could all potentially be targeted by inhibiting GSTO1-1, and a direct role for GSTO1-1 in some of these diseases has been strongly implicated.(8,9) Furthermore, GSTO1-1 is required for inflammatory-mediated photoreceptor death in degenerating retina,(10) identifying the enzyme as a potential therapeutic target for retina degradation that occurs in age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Additionally, diverse human cancers,(11−16) especially chemoresistant cancers,(17−19) were reported to be related to the abnormal expression of GSTO1-1.
    In previous studies, GSTO1-1 deficiency in mice and humans posed no adverse effects,(4) suggesting that GSTO1-1 may serve as a potential therapeutic target for a wide range of inflammation-related diseases. Several small molecules have been reported as GSTO1-1 inhibitors but have not progressed through preclinical development.(1,20−22) Most of these bear chemically reactive moieties and function as inhibitors through covalently labeling the GSTO1-1 active-site cysteine, Cys32. After undertaking a hit assessment of these compounds,(1) a benzenesulfonamide that contains a chloroacetamide warhead (C1-27) was selected as a preferred template around which to elaborate structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies. This compound was reported as a covalent binder to Cys32, with promising inhibitory activity toward both purified and endogenous GSTO1-1, promising selectivity of GSTO1-1 among the cell proteomes, and relevant activity, suppressing human colon cancer xenograft growth in nude mice.(23) Chloroacetamides have been reported as generally less-reactive electrophiles that are more selective toward thiols when compared with some other electrophilic functional groups.(24,25) Given also that published data suggested selective action against GSTO1-1, C1-27 stood out as a promising starting point for further investigation by our assessments.
    In the present study, we profiled C1-27 against more detailed lead-likeness criteria, synthesized three series of novel C1-27 analogues to investigate SAR, and evaluated the enzymatic inhibitory activities of analogues by the S-(4-nitrophenacyl)glutathione (4-NPG) assay.(26) In addition, the 4-NPG assay has been optimized, such that for the first time for any reported GSTO1-1 inhibitor, the kinact/KI values of selected compounds could be measured as a more informative evaluation of potency for covalent inhibitors.(27) We also tested the capacity of selected compounds to inhibit cytokine release from mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs), which reflects intracellular GSTO1-1 inhibition. The in vivo pharmacokinetics (PK) analysis of selected compounds was also performed. X-ray crystallographic analysis of selected compounds in complex with GSTO1-1 was performed to help rationalize the SAR.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Kinetic Solubility, Thiol Reactivity, In Vitro Metabolic Stability, and In Vivo PK Evaluation of C1-27

    Using nephelometry, the kinetic solubility of C1-27 in water and in saline (pH 7.4) was determined for both conditions to be 50–100 μg/mL, indicating that it is reasonably water-soluble for an early-stage compound.
    The thiol reactivity of C1-27 was also evaluated by “a La assay to detect reactive molecules by nuclear magnetic resonance” (ALARM NMR).(28,29) In this assay, human Lupus antigen (hLa) was used as a proteinaceous thiol-based probe to investigate the nonspecific protein thiol reactivity of C1-27. As shown in Figure 1, when the reducing agent dithiothreitol (DTT) was not included, 13C-labeled methyl groups in hLa underwent characteristic peak shifts and intensity decreases, which is consistent with formation of covalent adducts between hLa and C1-27. Thus, C1-27 was determined as positive in ALARM NMR, which means that, despite published reports, its thiol reactivity is not necessarily exclusive to GSTO1-1, at least in vitro. Although this does not preclude C1-27 as a development candidate, it does introduce an important aspect (selectivity) to be monitored during the optimization process.
    The in vitro metabolic stability of C1-27 was assessed with human and mouse liver microsomes with reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) as the cofactor. During a 60 min incubation, an NADPH-regenerating system was added and quenched at various time points when the concentration of the compound was measured. As no measurable concentration of C1-27 was detected past the first time point (i.e., 2 min) with human microsomes, its half-life was considered to be less than 2 min, whereas its half-life with mouse microsome was determined to be 7 min. Meanwhile, non-NADPH-mediated degradation of C1-27 was observed in both human and mouse microsome control samples. Therefore, C1-27 can be judged to be relatively susceptible to microsomal degradation.
    The pharmacokinetics of C1-27 was evaluated after a 30 mg/kg intraperitoneal (ip) dose was administered to male Swiss outbred mice. The maximum plasma concentration was observed at the first sampling time point (5 min postdose), indicative of rapid compound absorption. However, the compound concentration only remained above the analytical lower limit of quantitation (LLOQ, 0.0321 μM) for no longer than 1 h postdose, indicative of rapid elimination. The plasma concentration of C1-27 at the last sampling time point (1 h postdose) was insufficient to be quantified, so its apparent half-life could not be determined (Figure 2).

    Chemistry

    The synthesis of the first series of C1-27 analogues follows a general route described in Scheme 1. The sulfonic acid (1) was classically formed in good yield by stirring 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene in fuming sulfuric acid at 110 °C overnight(30) and subsequently transformed to various sulfonamides (2a–l) in good to excellent yields using classical amide formation reactions. Intermediates 2a–l were then reduced to corresponding anilines with an excess of zinc and ammonium chloride in methanol, followed by an N-acylation reaction to afford desired analogues 3a–j in good to excellent yields. Desired analogues 4k and 4l were obtained in good yields after hydrolysis of the respective esters in 3k and 3l with lithium hydroxide in methanol.
    Various synthetic routes were taken to access the second series of C1-27 analogues (Scheme 2). Amide analogues 6a–h were obtained in acceptable to good yields by N-acylation reactions between the aniline intermediate 5 and appropriate acid chlorides. The intermediate 5 was made by following the synthetic route in Scheme 1, and the acid chlorides were products of reactions between oxalyl chloride and corresponding carboxylic acids (Scheme 2A). Analogue 6i was formed in acceptable yield as an alkylated product of the nucleophilic substitution of intermediate 5 (Scheme 2A). For the synthesis of sulfonyl fluoride analogues 6j and 6k (Scheme 2A), the aniline starting point 5 was first transformed to the aryl bromide intermediate 7 via a Sandmeyer reaction in good yield.(31) Intermediate 7 was then transformed to the boronic acid 8 in acceptable yield using triisopropyl borate as the reagent and n-BuLi as a strong base. Methyllithium was applied as a dehydrating agent.(32) The desired analogue 6j was then formed by an oxidative boron-Heck coupling, which is compatible with the ethenesulfonyl fluoride functional group,(33) and the desired analogue 6k was subsequently formed by reducing the double bond of 6j with triethylsilane and Pd/C.(34)
    For the synthesis of another two sulfonyl fluoride analogues 6l and 6m (Scheme 2B), 4-chlorobenzoic acid was used as the starting material. The sulfonamide substituent was incorporated in good yield by stirring in chlorosulfonic acid at 150 °C overnight,(35) followed by an amidation. The resulting intermediate 10 was then reduced to an alcohol 11 in excellent yield,(36) which was subsequently transformed to the benzyl bromide 12 in excellent yield by a typical Appel reaction.(37) Analogue 6l was then obtained by attaching a sulfonyl fluoride group at the chain end,(38) while the chain-end sulfonyl fluoride of analogue 6m could not be attached until the chain was lengthened by a Stille coupling,(39) hydroboration–oxidation,(40) and Appel reaction.(37) The Stille coupling product—alkene intermediate 14—was also oxidized(41) to form the epoxide analogue 6n (Scheme 2B).
    The synthesis of another epoxide analogue 6o was accomplished by following the route shown in Scheme 2C. The Weinreb amide 16 was made in excellent yield from the carboxylic acid intermediate 10. After a Weinreb ketone synthesis,(42) the ketone intermediate 17 was afforded in excellent yield, which was subsequently brominated to intermediate 18 in good yield. The α-brominated ketone 18 was then reduced to an alcohol 19 in good yield with sodium borohydride,(43) followed by a cyclization to afford the epoxide 6o under basic conditions.(44)
    The synthetic routes of series 3 analogues and the hybrid compound 25 are shown in Scheme 3. For analogues 22a–c, sulfonic acid intermediates 20a–c were first formed by aromatic sulfonation(30) or Sandmeyer reactions(45,46) in acceptable to excellent yields, which were then transformed to the desired analogues by following the route described in Scheme 1. Specifically, tin(II) chloride was used as the reducing agent when reducing 21b to aniline,(47) as the zinc and ammonium chloride method did not work for this case. For analogue 22d, a Suzuki coupling(48) was first applied to form the biphenyl intermediate 21d. After a routine reduction and N-acylation, analogue 22d was afforded in good yield. The trifluoromethyl analogue 22e was derived from the iodo intermediate 21b. After a trifluoromethylation(49) via the trifluoromethylating reagent 2,2-difluoro-2-(fluorosulfonyl)acetate, 21b was successfully transformed to 21e in very good yield, and the desired analogue 22e was readily formed afterward with the next two steps. The hybrid compound 25 was synthesized by following a route similar to that of 22e, using morpholine instead of dimethylamine in the sulfonamide formation step.

    Cell-Free Inhibition of Recombinant GSTO1-1

    A 4-NPG assay utilizing the substrate S-(4-nitrophenacyl)glutathione (4-NPG) and recombinant GSTO1-1 was used to characterize the biochemical modulation of GSTO1-1 by test compounds. Under the catalysis of GSTO1-1, 4-NPG is reduced to 4-nitroacetophenone, which results in a decrease in UV absorbance at 305 nm. This absorbance change is proportional to the GSTO1-1 enzymatic activity.(26) The inhibitory activities of all three series of analogues against purified GSTO1-1 were analyzed via the 4-NPG assay, indicated by half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) values (Table 1).
    Table 1. Inhibitory Activities of Compounds Against Recombinant, Purified GSTO1-1
    In series 1 analogues, 3b, 3f, 3g, and 3h were identified as more potent by the IC50 value than C1-27. Analogue 3g was the most potent, with a considerably improved IC50 value than C1-27 (0.030 versus 0.13 μM). Changing the dimethylamino group of C1-27 to 2-methoxy-N-methylethaneamino group (3b) led to a marginal improvement of potency (IC50 value 0.08 μM), while lengthening the 2-methoxyethyl chain by inserting one more methylene (3c) returned approximate equipotency (IC50 value 0.16 μM) relative to C1-27. The same case applied to 3g and 3h, with the 2-methoxyethylamino analogue 3g (IC50 value 0.030 μM) being more potent than the 3-methoxypropylamino analogue 3h (IC50 value 0.11 μM). This indicated that a chain with two methylenes between the N and O atoms was more tolerated than one with three methylenes in between. Furthermore, by pairwise comparison of 3b with 3g (IC50 values 0.08 versus 0.030 μM) and 3c with 3h (IC50 values 0.16 versus 0.11 μM), N-substituted amino groups were more potent than N-substituted methylamino groups. However, for 3e (IC50 value 0.58 μM), its methylamino group appeared to be not favored here by leading to a more than 4-fold loss of activity versus C1-27. By pairwise comparison of 3b with 4l (IC50 values 0.08 versus 0.18 μM) and 3g with 4k (IC50 values 0.030 versus 0.7 μM), the chain-end methoxy group was determined to be slightly favorable as the respective primary alcohols 4l and 4k were relatively less inhibitory. The introduction of hydrophilic rings was tolerated for 3d and 3j with respective IC50 values of 0.16 and 0.20 μM, but for 3i (IC50 value 0.34 μM), an activity loss of around 3-fold versus C1-27 was evident. Interestingly, the introduction of an isopropylamino group here improved the potency of C1-27 by about 2-fold (compare 3f versus C1-27).
    Warheads generally associated with less reactivity than chloroacetamide were investigated in the series 2 analogues. Some of these warheads were selected based on their reported(27) rates of reactivity with glutathione (GSH). For example, the warheads of 6a, 6g, and 6h were reported to react with GSH with half-lives of >60, 17, and >60 h, respectively, while chloroacetamide had a half-life of 3.2 h, indicating the diminished reactivity of these warheads with GSH than chloroacetamide. Although the reactivity with GSH does not necessarily reflect the absolute reactivity with GSTO1-1 Cys32, we posited it as a reasonable basis on which to select compounds that are likely to be inherently less thiol-reactive. Other compounds such as 6c, 6e, and 6f were designed on the basis that they might plausibly form reversible covalent adducts, such as tetrahedral intermediates in the case of bis-carbonyls 6e and 6f or a thioimidate in the case of 6c.(50−52) With these presumably less-reactive warheads, series 2 analogues did not show enhanced or even comparable potency than C1-27. Introducing a methyl group at the adjacent methylene or inserting another methylene caused more than 100-fold reduction of inhibitory activity by IC50 value (6a and 6b versus C1-27). Substituting the chlorine for a cyano group or fluorine caused more than 1000-fold reduction of activity (6c and 6d versus C1-27). Both the acrylamide analogue 6g (IC50 value >1000 μM) and the 2-butenamide analogue 6h (IC50 > 100 μM) showed more than 1000-fold reduction of activity. Analogues 6e (IC50 > 10 μM) and 6f (IC50 values >1000 μM) also showed more than 100-fold reduction of activity. Bearing a less-reactive species, 6f was even less active than 6e. Other analogues without acetamide-type warheads such as 6i (IC50 > 100 μM) also showed a considerable drop in activity, but the IC50 values of 6l (0.8 μM) and 6o (1.2 μM) were intriguing enough to suggest the possible utility of their warheads. As one of the four sulfonyl fluoride analogues, 6l showed the strongest inhibitory activity among them (6l versus 6j, 6k, 6m), suggesting that with a one-carbon chain, the sulfonyl fluoride warhead could be placed in the best position to react with Cys32. With an IC50 value of 0.8 μM, 6l was also the only compound of the same magnitude of bioactivity as that of C1-27 among 6a–o. The epoxide analogue 6o had a comparable inhibitory activity with 6l (IC50 values 1.2 versus 0.8 μM), and the fact that 6n (IC50 > 100 μM) was much less active than 6o suggested that the epoxide group of 6o may have been in a good position to react with Cys32.
    Series 3 analogues 22a–e possess various hydrophobic functional groups in replacement of the chlorine of C1-27. These compounds were investigated on the basis that scrutiny of the published(23) complex of C1-27 with GSTO1-1 suggested an ability to accommodate larger hydrophobic groups in the binding site. After synthesis and testing, it was observed that compounds 22a–c were similar in activity to C1-27, with respective IC50 values of 0.15, 0.13, and 0.21 μM, while 22d was significantly less active (IC50 value = 0.71 μM). In contrast, the trifluoromethyl analogue 22e was more active than C1-27 (IC50 value = 0.060 μM). One of the possible explanations is that a more electronegative group might be better tolerated at this position (electronegativity: trifluoromethyl > chloro > bromo > iodo > trifluoromethoxy > phenyl).

    kinact/KI Determination

    With covalent reactive groups, all of the analogues were assumed to interact with GSTO1-1 in a model shown by eq 1, where first the inhibitor (I) binds to the target protein (P) by noncovalent interactions (KI), and a reversible protein–inhibitor complex (P·I) is thereby formed; then, a covalent bond is formed between them (kinact), resulting in a covalent protein–inhibitor complex (P–I). Here, the KI term describes the concentration of the inhibitor required for half-maximal inhibition, and the kinact is a first-order rate constant describing the maximum potential rate of covalent bond formation.(1,53)(1)Taken together, the overall rate of covalent bond formation from P to P–I is defined by kinact/KI, and this ratio is thought to be a more suitable index to evaluate the potency of a covalent inhibitor compared to simple IC50 values.(27) Best practice dictates that IC50 studies should be restricted to preliminary investigations and the incorporation of kinact/KI during an SAR campaign is most recommended.(53) Hence, the kinact/KI values of selected analogues were determined (Table 2). The 4-NPG spectrophotometric assay and the change in absorbance at 305 nm were used to determine the enzyme rate (E). The enzyme was then incubated with different concentrations of inhibitor (see the Experimental Section) for 1, 2, 4, and 6 min before determining the enzymatic rate (Et). The enzymatic rate without the inhibitor was determined to provide the initial uninhibited activity (E0). According to eq 2, the observed first-order rate constant kobs is provided by the negative slope of a plot of ln(Et/E0) versus time (t). From eq 3, the KI and kinact can be calculated from a plot of 1/kobs versus 1/[I] ([I]: inhibitor concentration), with KI/kinact equivalent to the slope and 1/kinact as the Y intercept.(54)(2)(3)A typical example of the analysis of a GSTO1-1 inhibitor (6l) is shown in Figure 3. As shown in Figure 3A, the plots of ln(Et/E0) versus time at inhibitor concentrations of 200, 500, 1000, and 1500 nM were analyzed by linear regression analysis, yielding −kobs as the slope at each concentration. Then, as shown in Figure 3B, the plot of 1/kobs versus 1/[I] shows an acceptable linear relationship (R2 > 0.99), yielding values for KI and kinact.
    Table 2. kinact/KI Values of Selected Compounds
     C1-273b3d3f3g3h6l6o22e
    kinact (min–1)0.780.618.13.00.801.32.30.471.1
    KI (μM)0.446.96.74.82.59.99.65.01.2
    kinact/KI (×104 M–1 s–1)3.00.152.01.00.530.220.400.161.5
    As shown in Table 2, none of the selected analogues showed better kinact/KI values than C1-27, although 3b, 3f–h, and 22e had smaller IC50 values than C1-27. Of these, the morpholino analogue 3d and the trifluoromethyl analogue 22e appeared to be the most active, with kinact/KI of 2.0 × 104 and 1.5 × 104 M–1 s–1. The KI values of all analogues were larger than that of C1-27, indicating that they had weaker noncovalent interactions with GSTO1-1. Among them, 22e had the smallest KI, which was 1.2 μM, followed by 3g with a KI of 2.5 μM. The kinact value was not necessarily determined by the intrinsic reactivity of the covalent reactive group but was related to the molecule as a whole. For example, analogues 3b, 3d, 3f–h, and 22e possess the same covalent reactive group as C1-27, but all of these compounds had various kinact values. Of these, 3d appeared to be the most reactive, followed by 3f, 3h, and 22e, then 3g and 3b, which showed similar reactivity to C1-27. It is possible that once in position, certain hydrogen-bond-accepting groups in some ligands may be favorably positioned to activate the nearby active-site cysteine side chain. Also, although with a less-reactive warhead, 6l appeared to be more reactive than C1-27, indicated by its much larger kinact value. On the contrary, 6o, which also has a less-reactive warhead, showed less reactivity than C1-27, with a kinact value of 0.47 min–1. This implies that the sulfonyl fluoride of 6l might be placed in a better position to react with the enzyme than the chloroacetamide of C1-27 and the epoxide of 6o.

    Intracellular GSTO1-1 Inhibition

    To test the capacity of selected inhibitors to modulate the function of the NLRP3 inflammasome, we prepared mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs) and measured the release of IL-1β after stimulation with bacterial LPS and adenosine 5′-triphosphate (ATP). The biomarker used in this assay, IL-1β, is strongly dependent on GSTO1-1 activity and a reasonable measure of intracellular GSTO1-1 inhibition.(3)
    As shown in Figure 4, after treatment with 5 μM C1-27, the release of IL-1β decreased significantly to 66.8 ± 5.1% of that in untreated BMDMs. Importantly, when we tested the negative control 6g, which is inactive toward GSTO1-1 yet for which the only difference with C1-27 is replacement of the chloromethylamide with a reactive acrylamide, very little cellular activity was observed (92.8 ± 4.9% IL-1β release relative to wild-type (WT) cells). This supports the suggestion that the release of IL-1β detected in this assay correlates well with GSTO1-1 inhibition. Series 1 analogues 3b, 3c, 3d, 3f, and 3g all showed greater inhibition than C1-27, with 61.3 ± 6.8, 41.5 ± 2.5, 24.3 ± 2.2, 36.0 ± 2.8, and 47.8 ± 5.1% IL-1β release relative to untreated BMDMs. Among them, the morpholino analogue 3d was the most active, even among all tested compounds. Series 2 analogues 6l and 6o also showed better intracellular inhibitory activity than C1-27, with IL-1β concentrations decreased to 39.8 ± 2.5 and 43.7 ± 2.0% of untreated cells, respectively. As 6l was a poorer inhibitor of purified GSTO1-1 than C1-27 and with a smaller kinact/KI, this level of cellular activity was unexpected, although lacking the amide group of C1-27, both compounds may be able to penetrate cells in significantly higher concentrations. Sulfonyl fluorides have been reported to react relatively readily with a variety of protein nucleophiles,(55) and it is possible that modulation of additional pathways controlling IL-1β release might contribute to the cell-based readout.
    With a lower IC50 value than C1-27 with purified GSTO1-1, the series 3 analogue 22e also showed a much greater cellular inhibition than C1-27 (27.5 ± 1.5% IL-1β release relative to WT), indicating its good ability to inhibit both purified and intracellular GSTO1-1.

    Mice PK Analysis

    Based on biochemical and intracellular analyses, the most promising analogues 3d and 22e were evaluated for key PK parameters in mice. With an aim of comparison with C1-27, the PK analysis was conducted under the same conditions as that for C1-27. The two analogues were administered to male Swiss outbred mice following ip administration at a target dose of 30 mg/kg, followed by plasma collection at specified postdose time points. As shown in Figure 5, like C1-27, the maximum plasma concentrations of 3d and 22e were observed at the first sampling time point (5 min postdose), being 3.87 and 11.60 μM, respectively, indicating that these two analogues were also absorbed rapidly, and analogue 22e showed a better absorption than C1-27. The plasma concentration of 3d remained above the LLOQ (0.0071 μM) up to 1 h postdose and that of 22e remained above the LLOQ (0.0015 μM) up to 2 h, suggesting a slower elimination of these two analogues than C1-27 whose plasma concentration only remained above the LLOQ (0.0321 μM) for no longer than 1 h.

    Crystallography

    The cocrystal structures of GSTO1-1 in complex with selected series 1 analogues 3b, 3d, and 3f were solved (Figure 6A–C). The collection of highly redundant X-ray data aided the interpretation of electron density around the inhibitor, which appeared to demonstrate alternative conformations in the active site for some ligands. A covalent bond between compounds and Cys32 was observed in all cases. The three compounds bind with a dominant conformer in which the amide, phenyl ring, and sulfamoyl groups overlap. These feature T-shaped π-stacking interactions between phenyl rings and Phe34, with the various moieties attached at the sulfamoyl group located between Ile131, Trp222, and Tyr229. Based on electron density, these groups appear to be poorly ordered. A water-mediated hydrogen bond was observed between the Trp180 indole ring NH and one sulfamoyl oxygen atom. In the cases of 3b and 3f, two additional water-mediated hydrogen bonds were observed between the alternative sulfamoyl oxygen atom and Arg183Nε1, and the Trp222 indole ring NH. As shown in Figure 6E, two conformers of the morpholino analogue 3d were modeled. The dominant conformer (Figure 6B) overlays with 3b and 3f and is bound in a manner distinct from C1-27 (Figure 6D,F). The amide groups of 3b, 3d, and 3f are flipped approximately 180° with respect to the amide group in C1-27. Nevertheless, the sulfonamide groups of 3b, 3d, and 3f and C1-27 overlap. The minor conformer of 3d adopts a unique pose. The compound has shifted laterally toward Trp222, with compensatory rotation of the Cys32 Cα–Cβ bond (Figure 3E). The morpholino ring of 3d has displaced the indole ring of Trp222, forcing it to rotate 120°.
    According to the reported(23) structure of C1-27 in complex with GSTO1-1, the sulfonyl group and the phenyl ring of C1-27 were critical for its binding to GSTO1-1. In contrast, the dimethylamino group in the sulfonamide moiety should be able to be extended because it is at the surface of GSTO1-1 and pointing away from the protein surface. Thus, we substituted several longer chains and bulkier groups at this position, with a focus on hydrophilic substituents to further improve the water solubility of C1-27. This was driven by a perceived future utility of a GSTO1-1 inhibitor in settings of Gram-negative bacterial sepsis, where intravenous administration would be tolerated and require high water solubility. However, as suggested by the crystallographic analysis of 3b, 3d, and 3f, we have shown that such compounds are able to adopt an alternative conformation when binding to GSTO1-1. As shown in Figure 6, instead of pointing to the solvent like the dimethylamino group of C1-27, their various amino groups were located in an enzyme pocket and tended to be poorly ordered. This explained why some of the longer chains were well-tolerated here, as they were flexible enough to fit the surrounding cavity. For example, the 2-methoxyethylamino group proved to be the most favored (3g, GSTO1-1 IC50 = 0.030 μM, kinact/KI = 5.3 × 103 M–1 s–1).

    Development of a Hybrid Compound of 3d and 22e

    A noteworthy outcome of this exercise was the better cell-based activity observed for the morpholino analogue 3d (IL-1β relative to WT = 24.3 ± 2.2% at a concentration of 5 μM) compared with C1-27. This contrasts with the GSTO1-1 biochemical inhibition assay, where this compound was not more potent than C1-27, but rather was slightly weaker (GSTO1-1 IC50 = 0.16 μM). Additionally, its kinact/KI value of 2.0 × 104 M–1 s–1 was the second highest of all compounds tested. The kinact/KI of C1-27 was higher still but was less active in cells, suggesting that additional factors may contribute to cell-based activity. One possibility is that the hydrophobic bulk of the morpholino group in the vicinity of sulfonyl oxygen atoms aids in desolvation and transport through cellular membranes, giving rise to relatively increased cell-based activities.
    The other prominent compound in terms of cell-based activity was 22e (IL-1β relative to WT = 27.5 ± 1.5% at a concentration of 5 μM). This compound was slightly more potent than C1-27 against GSTO1-1 for biochemical inhibition (GSTO1-1 IC50 = 0.060 μM) and was also noteworthy in that its kinact/KI value of 1.5 × 104 M–1 s–1 was the third highest of all compounds tested. However, these observations alone cannot account for its remarkably potent cell-based activity. The trifluoromethyl group of 22e is more akin in size to an isopropyl group,(56−59) and it is possible that this could also encourage desolvation of the nearby sulfonyl group to result in increased membrane permeability.
    To determine whether the cellular potencies of 3d and 22e could be captured in a single, more potent compound, the hybrid compound 25 was targeted. This was synthesized by following the route shown in Scheme 3, combining the morpholino group of 3d with the trifluoromethyl group of 22e. As shown in Table 3, the biochemical, intracellular, and PK analyses of the hybrid compound 25 were conducted.
    Table 3. IC50, kinact/KI, Cellular Activity, and PK Analysis of the Hybrid Compound 25
    IC50 (μM)kinact (min–1)KI (μM)kinact/KI (M–1 s–1)% IL-1β release relative to [email protected] μMt1/2 (h)Cmax (μM)
    0.25 ± 0.030.850.612.3 × 1043.4 ± 1.41.46.37
    The IC50 value of 25 was slightly higher than that of C1-27 (0.25 versus 0.13 μM), and its kinact/KI value was also slightly lower (2.3 × 104 versus 3.0 × 104 M–1 s–1), suggesting that compound 25 had a slightly weaker enzymatic inhibitory activity than C1-27, yet its kinact/KI value was the highest among all other tested analogues, including 3d and 22e. The KI value of 25 was also much smaller than all analogues except for C1-27 and only slightly higher than that of C1-27, suggesting that 25 had the strongest noncovalent interactions with GSTO1-1 among all novel analogues. More interestingly, the cellular activity of compound 25 was impressive. After treatment with 5 μM 25, the IL-1β release decreased to 3.4 ± 1.4% of that in untreated cells, suggesting the strongest intracellular inhibitory activity of 25 among all compounds. In other words, compound 25 was observed to be much more active in cells than not only C1-27 but also 3d and 22e. We believe this supports the fact that the kinact/KI value aligns well with cellular activity, albeit that it is unlikely to be the sole governing factor.
    The PK analysis of compound 25 was conducted under the same conditions as C1-27, 3d, and 22e. After ip administration to male Swiss outbred mice at a target dose of 30 mg/kg, the plasma concentrations of compound 25 at specified postdose time points were calculated. Like C1-27, 3d, and 22e, its maximum plasma concentration was detected at the first sampling time point (5 min postdose), being 6.37 μM, indicating its similarly rapid absorption and high exposure. The plasma concentration of 25 remained above the LLOQ (0.0065 μM) up to 4 h postdose, and its half-life was calculated to be around 1.4 h, suggesting slower elimination of this compound than C1-27, 3d, and 22e.

    Development of Chloromethylamides as Drug Candidates

    Chloromethylamide-containing compounds would generally be viewed by medicinal chemists as in need of reactivity moderation before consideration as drug candidates. With this in mind, the α-chloroacetamide of C1-27 was changed to other less-reactive surrogates with an aim of diminishing the reactivity of the molecule. For series 2 analogues in particular, this was partly guided by published reports for functional group thiol reactivity.(27,60) Among all series 2 analogues, 6l (GSTO1-1 IC50 = 0.8 μM) and 6o (GSTO1-1 IC50 = 1.2 μM) alone returned GSTO1-1 biochemical inhibitory activity, albeit considerably less than C1-27. These two analogues also showed slightly better cellular activities than C1-27 (IL-1β relative to WT = 39.8 ± 2.5 and 43.7 ± 2.0%, versus C1-27 IL-1β relative to WT = 66.8 ± 5.1%). Considering that epoxide has been used in 16 marketed drugs (based on search via Cortellis) and 6o noncovalently bound to the enzyme well (KI = 5.0 μM), epoxide-containing GSTO1-1 inhibitors may represent alternatives to α-chloroacetamides for future optimization. A very impressive recent report from the Neamati group(20) has disclosed acrylamide-based compounds as potent GSTO1-1 inhibitors, further supporting the case that chloromethylamide alternatives are possible. However, no cell-based activity was reported for these compounds.
    Although C1-27 and 25 are both relatively rapidly cleared in mice, which is reflected in their relatively short in vivo half-lives, they are rapidly absorbed and their Cmax values are high, at around 9 μM for C1-27 and 6 μM for 25. We suggest that irreversible inhibition could still allow for this compound class to be suitable for in vivo proof-of-concept studies, and indeed a published report(23) as well as our publication(3) is to this effect in the case of C1-27. However, given the results of our cell-based assay, for any such studies going forward, we would promote variant 25 as a preferred tool compound for monitoring the effects in vitro and in vivo of pharmacological inhibition of GSTO1-1.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The GSTO1-1 inhibitor C1-27 was profiled for its suitability as an in vitro and in vivo biochemical probe of GSTO1-1 pharmacological inhibition. Properties that included solubility, thiol reactivity, metabolic stability in vitro, and PK in mice were assessed, and the complex of C1-27 bound to GSTO1-1 was analyzed. Based on this assessment, three series of analogues were designed, synthesized, and tested for their biological activity. X-ray crystallographic structural analysis of selected compounds was also undertaken to further characterize the observed SAR. Several of these compounds showed higher potency than C1-27 toward purified GSTO1-1, and two, in particular, 3d and 22e, were superior in cell-based assays of GSTO1-1 inhibition. The hybrid compound 25 combining the morpholino group of 3d with the trifluoromethyl group of 22e showed an even better cell-based activity. This could partly, but not completely, be explained by the binding kinetics data derived from an adapted 4-NPG assay that for the first time allows determination of kinact/KI for inhibitors of GSTO1-1.
    Although these compounds are relatively rapidly cleared after ip administration, given their rapid absorption and high Cmax, a mechanism involving irreversible inactivation may still allow for their use as in vivo tool compounds in animal models of GSTO1-1 inhibition, and the use of C1-27 has already been reported in this context.(23) Indeed, rapid clearance may be regarded as a favorable attribute to mitigate against the likelihood of off-target toxicity. A key finding of the current study was the relatively potent cell-based activity of compound 25, which we believe represents the best GSTO1-1 inhibitor reported to date in this context.
    The cell-based assay measures IL-1β release as a surrogate of GSTO1-1 intracellular inhibition. Although this is not proof of specific GSTO1-1 occupancy, we believe it stands as one of the current best options as a cell-based assay for triage of GSTO1-1 inhibitors. In addition, by isolating liver lysate and measuring GSTO1-1 activity with the 4-NPG assay, we have recently shown(3) greatly reduced activity of intracellular GSTO1-1 in mice after treatment with C1-27, supporting the validity of linking IL-1β release to GSTO1-1 intracellular inhibition.
    Nevertheless, that C1-27 is positive in the ALARM NMR assay merits some caution and suggests that this compound class may have the ability to engage in off-target readouts. That said, there is recent evidence that GSTO1-1 may be the most reactive cysteine residue in the cysteome(61) and may therefore be selectively inactivated in preference to off-targets with less-reactive active-site cysteines. Until such time that demonstrably benign alternative GSTO1-1 inhibitors are developed, we suggest that for researchers interested in determination of biological responses to GSTO1-1 inhibition, 25 represents a significant advance toward useful biochemical tools for such purposes.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Lead-Likeness Evaluation of C1-27

    Kinetic Solubility Estimation Using Nephelometry (SolpH)

    The compound in DMSO was spiked into either pH 7.4 phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) or Milli-Q water with the final DMSO concentration being 1% (v/v). After 30 min of incubation, samples were then analyzed via nephelometry to determine a solubility range.(62)

    ALARM NMR

    The test compound or positive control (400 μM final concentration) or the DMSO vehicle was incubated with purified recombinant 13C-methyl-labeled hLa (50 μM final concentration) with or without 20 mM DTT at 37 °C for 1 h and then at 30 °C for 15 h prior to data collection. Data were recorded at 37 °C on a Bruker 700 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with a cryoprobe (Bruker) and an autosampler. Samples were loaded into Bruker 1.7 mM SampleJet tubes with 40 μL total sample volumes and stored at 4 °C while in queue. The ALARM NMR samples were tested using 16 scans, 2048 complex points in F2, and 80 points in F1 using standard protein HMQC and water suppression pulse sequences. Grossly nonreactive compounds are identified by the absence of chemical shifts (13C-methyl) ±20 mM DTT. Reactive compounds are identified by characteristic peak shifts and attenuations in the absence of DTT, with this effect significantly attenuated when 20 mM DTT is included in an otherwise identical sample.(63)

    Metabolic Evaluation

    The compound was incubated in human liver microsomes (XenoTech, lot # 1410230) and mouse liver microsomes (XenoTech, lot # 1510256) at 37 °C with a substrate concentration of 1 μM and a protein concentration of 0.4 mg/mL. The metabolic reaction was initiated by the addition of an NADPH-regenerating system and quenched at various time points over a 60 min incubation period by the addition of acetonitrile containing diazepam as the internal standard (IS). The control sample (containing no NADPH) was included (and quenched at 2, 30, and 60 min) to monitor for potential degradation in the absence of a cofactor. Samples were analyzed by ultraperformance liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (UPLC–MS) (Waters/Micromass Xevo G2 QTOF) under positive electrospray ionization (ESI). Compound concentration versus time data were fitted to an exponential decay function to determine the first-order rate constant (k) for substrate depletion, which was then used to calculate a degradation half-life.

    Mice PK Evaluation

    The compound was formulated at a concentration of 3.0 mg/mL in 10% (v/v) DMSO/90% (v/v) aqueous cyclodextrin solution and then administered to nonfasted male Swiss outbred mice weighing 22.1–33.8 g via a single injection into the ip cavity (10 mL/kg dose volume) at 30 mg/kg. Mice had access to food and water ad libitum throughout the predose and postdose sampling periods. The blood samples were collected pre, 0.083, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 7.5, and 24 h postdose (n = 3 mice per time point) with a maximum of three samples from each mouse. Samples were collected either via submandibular bleed (approximately 120 μL; conscious sampling) or via terminal cardiac puncture (0.4 mL; under anesthesia using inhaled isoflurane). Blood was collected into polypropylene Eppendorf tubes containing heparin as the anticoagulant and stabilization cocktail (containing Complete (a protease inhibitor cocktail) and potassium fluoride) to minimize the potential for ex vivo compound degradation. Once collected, blood samples were centrifuged immediately and the supernatant plasma was removed. Plasma samples were quantified against calibration standards prepared by spiking blank mouse plasma (50 μL) with solution standards (10 μL) obtained by diluting a stock solution of the test compound (1 mg/mL in DMSO) with 50% acetonitrile in water. Diazepam (10 μL of 5 μg/mL in 50% acetonitrile/water) was added to all plasma calibration standards and samples as an internal standard (IS). The extraction of the test compound and IS from plasma was conducted using protein precipitation with acetonitrile. Protein precipitation was carried out by the addition of acetonitrile followed by vortexing and centrifugation (10 000 rpm) for 3 min to obtain the supernatant for analysis by UPLC–MS (Waters Xevo TQS Micro coupled to a Waters Acquity UPLC) under ion polarity switching electrospray ionization. This animal study was conducted using established procedures in accordance with the Australian Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes, and the study protocol was reviewed and approved by the Monash Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences Animal Ethics Committee.

    Chemistry

    All characterized compounds had a purity of >95% as measured by analytical reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). Solvents were of analytical grade. Analytical reversed-phase HPLC was acquired on an Agilent 1260 Infinity analytical HPLC coupled with a G1322A degasser, a G1312B binary pump, a G1367E high-performance autosampler, and a G4212B diode array detector. Conditions: Zorbax Eclipse Plus C18 Rapid resolution column (4.6 × 100 mm2) with UV detection at 254 and 214 nm, 30 °C; the sample was eluted using a gradient of 5–100% of solvent B in solvent A where solvent A: 0.1% aqueous trifluoroacetyl (TFA), and solvent B: 0.1% TFA in ACN (5–100% B [9 min], 100% B [1 min]; 1.0 mL/min).
    Analytical thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was performed on silica gel 60/F254 precoated aluminum sheets (0.25 mm, Merck). Flash column chromatography was carried out with silica gel 60, 0.63–0.20 mm (70–230 mesh, Merck). 1H, 19F, and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 400.13, 376.42, and 100.62 MHz, respectively, on a Bruker Avance III Nanobay spectrometer with BACS 60 sample changer, using solvents from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories. Chemical shifts (δ, ppm) are reported relative to the solvent peak (CDCl3: 7.26 [1H] or 77.16 [13C]; methanol-d4: 3.31 [1H] or 49.00 [13C]; DMSO-d6: 2.50 [1H] or 39.52 [13C]) or CFCl3 at 0.00 [19F]. Proton resonances are annotated as follows: chemical shift (ppm), multiplicity (s, singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; q, quartet; m, multiplet; dd, doublet of doublets; dt, doublet of triplets; td, triplet of doublets; br, broad signal), coupling constant (J, Hz), and number of protons.
    Liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS) was performed on an Agilent 6100 Series Single Quad LC–MS coupled with an Agilent 1200 series HPLC, a G1311A quaternary pump, a G1329A thermostatted autosampler, and a G1314B variable wavelength detector (214 and 254 nm). LC conditions: Phenomenex Luna C8(2) column (100 Å, 5 μm, 50 × 4.6 mm2), 30 °C; the sample (5 μL) was eluted using a binary gradient (solvent A: 0.1% aq HCO2H; solvent B: 0.1% HCO2H in ACN; 5–100% B [4 min], 100% B [7 min]; 100–5% B [9 min], 5% B [10 min]; 0.5 mL/min). MS conditions: quadrupole ion source with multimode-ESI; drying gas temperature, 300 °C; vaporizer temperature, 200 °C; capillary voltage, 2000 V (positive mode) or 4000 V (negative mode); scan range, 100–1000 m/z; step size, 0.1 s over 10 min.
    High-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) was performed on an Agilent 6224 TOF LC–MS coupled to an Agilent 1290 Infinity LC. All data were acquired and reference mass corrected via a dual-spray ESI source. Each scan or data point on the total ion chromatogram (TIC) is an average of 13 700 transients, producing a spectrum every second. Mass spectra were created by averaging the scans across each peak and subtracting the background from the first 10 s of the TIC. Acquisition was performed using Agilent Mass Hunter Data Acquisition software version B.05.00 Build 5.0.5042.2, and analysis was performed using Mass Hunter Qualitative Analysis version B.05.00 Build 5.0.519.13. Acquisition parameters: mode, ESI; drying gas flow, 11 L/min; nebulizer pressure, 45 psi; drying gas temperature, 325 °C; voltages: capillary, 4000 V; fragmentor, 160 V; skimmer, 65 V; octopole RF, 750 V; scan range, 100–1500 m/z; positive ion mode internal reference ions, m/z 121.050873 and 922.009798. LC conditions: Agilent Zorbax SB-C18 Rapid Resolution HT (2.1 × 50 mm2, 1.8 μm column), 30 °C; the sample (5 μL) was eluted using a binary gradient (solvent A: 0.1% aq HCO2H; solvent B: 0.1% HCO2H in ACN; 5–100% B [3.5 min], 0.5 mL/min).

    General Procedure A

    The appropriate 1-halo-4-nitrobenzene was dissolved in fuming sulfuric acid (20% SO3) with good agitation at 0 °C. The mixture was heated to 110 °C with vigorous stirring and left overnight. Once the reaction was completed, the mixture was cooled to rt and poured into an appropriate volume of 15% NaCl solution at 5 °C. The resulting mixture was extracted with EtOAc (×3), and the organic layers were combined. After the solvent was evaporated, the residue was dried in a vacuum oven at 55 °C overnight. The desired product was then obtained without further purification.

    General Procedure B

    To a solution of sulfonic acid (1.0 equiv) in thionyl chloride (10 mL) was added DMF (one drop). The reaction mixture was refluxed overnight. The excess of thionyl chloride was removed in vacuo, and the residue was azeotroped with toluene (×3). The resulting residue was dissolved in THF, and Et3N (1.5 equiv) was added. The reaction mixture was cooled to 0 °C on an ice bath. The appropriate amine (1.0 equiv) was added dropwise, and the reaction mixture was slowly warmed to rt until the reaction was completed (monitored by TLC). With no workup, the crude mixture was directly purified by column chromatography to afford the desired product.

    General Procedure C

    To a solution of the appropriate nitrobenzene in methanol at 40 °C was added zinc dust (10 equiv). The reaction mixture was cooled to rt, and aq NH4Cl (10 equiv) was added dropwise. Once the completion of reaction was shown by TLC, the mixture was filtered and washed with methanol (×3). The filtrate was concentrated, and the resulting residue was taken up into EtOAc and washed with H2O. The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and concentrated in vacuo to give the desired product.

    General Procedure D

    To a mixture of the appropriate aniline (1.0 equiv) and Et3N (1.1 equiv) in THF was added the appropriate acyl chloride (1.1 equiv) dropwise at 0 °C. The reaction was stirred at rt until the starting material was consumed (monitored by TLC). The mixture was filtered, and the residue was washed with THF. The filtrate was concentrated and purified by column chromatography to afford the desired product.

    General Procedure E

    To a stirred solution of the appropriate carboxylic acid (1.3 equiv) in DCM (0.1 M final concentration) were added oxalyl chloride (1.2 equiv) and DMF (one drop) at 0 °C. After the reaction mixture was stirred at rt for 3 h, the appropriate aniline (1.0 equiv) and Et3N (1.1 equiv) were added at 0 °C. The resulting mixture was allowed to warm to rt and stirred at rt until the reaction was completed (monitored by TLC). The solvent was removed, and the residue was taken up into EtOAc and washed with H2O and brine. The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20–35% EtOAc/petroleum benzene (PB) to give the desired product.

    General Procedure F

    To a solution of appropriate carboxylic acid (2.0 equiv) in DCM (0.1 M final concentration) were added oxalyl chloride (1.5 equiv) and DMF (one drop) at 0 °C. After the reaction mixture was stirred at rt for 3 h, this solution was added dropwise to a stirred solution of appropriate aniline (1.0 equiv) and Et3N (1.1 equiv) in DCM at 0 °C. The resulting mixture was allowed to warm to rt and stirred overnight. With no workup, the crude product was directly purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20–50% EtOAc/PB to give the desired product.

    General Procedure G

    To a solution of appropriate ester (1.0 equiv) in methanol was added 1 M lithium hydroxide solution (1.1 equiv) at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at rt until the starting material was consumed (monitored by TLC). The solvent was removed, and the residue was taken up into EtOAc and washed with H2O and brine. The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 50% EtOAc/PB to give the desired product.

    General Procedure H

    The corresponding sulfonyl chloride (1 equiv) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5 mL). Potassium fluoride (5 equiv) and TBAF (0.1 equiv) were added under rt. The reaction mixture was stirred at rt overnight. The solvent was evaporated under vacuum to give the crude product, which was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 10% EtOAc/PB.

    General Procedure I

    The iodobenzene (1 equiv) and copper(I) iodide (0.2 equiv) were dissolved in dry DMF under N2 protection. 2,2-Difluoro-2-(fluorosulfonyl)acetate (4 equiv) was added via a syringe. The reaction mixture was stirred at 70 °C overnight. After being cooled to rt, the reaction mixture was poured into water and extracted with EtOAc (×3). The organic layers were combined and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography to give the desired product.

    2-Chloro-5-nitrobenzenesulfonic Acid (1)

    It was prepared according to general procedure A (0.73 g, 81% yield). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 8.63 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 1H), 8.18 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 146.9, 145.9, 138.2, 132.6, 125.2, 124.0; LC–MS Rt 1.26 min, m/z [M – H]− 235.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + Na]+ for C6H4ClNO5SNa+ calcd 259.9391, found 259.9394.

    2-Chloro-N,N-dimethyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (2a)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.09 g, 54% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.89 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 8.33 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.73 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 2.96 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.2, 139.0, 138.6, 133.3, 127.6, 127.0, 37.5, 37.5; LC–MS Rt 3.20 min, m/z [M + H]+ 264.7; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C8H10ClN2O4S+ calcd 265.0044, found 265.0039.

    2-Chloro-N-(2-methoxyethyl)-N-methyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (2b)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.24 g, 60% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.84 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.25 (m, 1H), 7.64 (m, 1H), 3.47 (m, 2H), 3.42 (m, 2H), 3.20 (s, 3H), 2.98 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.1, 139.7, 139.0, 133.0, 127.4, 126.8, 70.8, 58.8, 49.8, 35.9.

    2-Chloro-N-(3-methoxypropyl)-N-methyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (2c)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.33 g, 82% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.80 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.25 (dt, J = 5.4, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.66 (m, 1H), 3.31 (m, 4H), 3.20 (s, 3H), 2.89 (s, 3H), 1.78 (dq, J = 8.2, 6.0 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.1, 139.3, 138.8, 133.3, 127.6, 126.9, 69.3, 58.6, 47.6, 34.7, 28.1; LC–MS Rt 3.54 min, m/z [M + H]+ 322.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H16ClN2O5S+ calcd 323.0463, found 323.0461.

    4-((2-Chloro-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)morpholine (2d)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.12 g, 62% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.87 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.37 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (m, 1H), 3.75 (m, 4H), 3.37 (m, 4H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.2, 138.9, 138.0, 133.5, 128.0, 127.0, 66.4, 66.4, 45.9, 45.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H12ClN2O5S+ calcd 307.0150, found 307.0144.

    2-Chloro-N-methyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (2e)

    To a solution of 1 (1.0 equiv) in thionyl chloride (10 mL) was added DMF (one drop). The reaction mixture was refluxed overnight. The excess of thionyl chloride was removed, and the residue was azeotroped with toluene (×3). The resulting residue was dissolved in DCM (2 mL). A mixture of methylamine hydrochloride (1 equiv) in H2O (2 mL) and 2 M aqueous potassium hydroxide (2 equiv) was stirred for 1 h at rt. Then, the DCM solution was added, and the resulting reaction mixture was stirred vigorously at rt until the starting material was consumed (monitored by TLC). The organic layer was separated out, washed with H2O and brine, and dried with MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20–100% EtOAc/PB (containing 1% Et3N), affording the title compound as an off-white solid (0.08 g, 40% yield). 1H NMR (methanol-d4, 400 MHz): δ = 8.82 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.42 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.87–7.83 (m, 1H), 2.62 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (methanol-d4, 101 MHz): δ = 146.3, 138.2, 133.1, 127.7, 125.9, 27.8; LC–MS Rt 3.38 min, m/z [M – H]− 248.8.

    2-Chloro-N-methyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (2f)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.23 g, 65% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.96 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.35 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.73 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 4.91 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 3.61–3.49 (m, 1H), 1.13 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.4, 140.4, 138.1, 132.8, 127.7, 126.1, 47.0, 23.6, 23.6.

    2-Chloro-N-(2-methoxyethyl)-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (2g)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.27 g, 93% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.89 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.34 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.73 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 5.59 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 3.40–3.35 (m, 2H), 3.22 (s, 3H), 3.19 (dd, J = 5.7, 4.7 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.3, 139.6, 138.4, 132.8, 127.8, 126.1, 70.4, 58.7, 43.3; LC–MS Rt 3.10 min, m/z [M – H]− 292.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H12ClN2O5S+ calcd 295.0150, found 295.0146.
