    It was prepared according to general procedure E (0.04 g, 35% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.34 (s, 1H), 8.06 (m, 2H), 7.50 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 5.00 (s, 1H), 4.88 (s, 1H), 2.91 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 166.0 (d, JC–F = 17.0 Hz), 136.7, 135.7, 132.8, 127.5, 124.8, 123.2, 80.1 (d, JC–F = 188.0 Hz), 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 3.05 min, m/z [M + H]+ 294.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13ClFN2O3S+ calcd 295.0314, found 295.0309.

    N-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)-2-oxopropanamide (6e)

    It was prepared according to general procedure F (0.04 g, 31% yield). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 10.91 (s, 1H), 8.50 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 8.09 (dd, J = 8.8, 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 2.84 (s, 6H), 2.44 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 196.5, 160.3, 137.6, 136.1, 133.1, 125.8, 125.5, 122.8, 37.7, 37.7, 25.0; LC–MS Rt 3.24 min, m/z [M + H]+ 304.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H14ClN2O4S+ calcd 305.0357, found 305.0359.

    N1-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)oxalamide (6f)

    It was prepared according to general procedure F (0.002 g, 2% yield). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 11.13 (s, 1H), 8.51 (d, J = 2.5 Hz, 1H), 8.38 (s, 1H), 8.09 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.6 Hz, 1H), 8.05 (s, 1H), 7.69 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 2.85 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 162.0, 159.9, 137.6, 136.1, 133.1, 125.9, 125.5, 122.6, 37.7, 37.7; LC–MS Rt 3.03 min, m/z [M + H]+ 305.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13ClN3O4S+ calcd 306.0310, found 306.0311.

    N-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)acrylamide (6g)

    It was prepared according to general procedure E (0.02 g, 18% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.19 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.5 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.40 (m, 1H), 6.39 (dd, J = 16.9, 1.3 Hz, 1H), 6.26 (dd, J = 16.9, 10.1 Hz, 1H), 5.73 (dd, J = 10.1, 1.3 Hz, 1H), 2.82 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 164.2, 137.5, 135.7, 132.8, 130.7, 128.7, 126.3, 125.0, 122.9, 37.5, 37.5; LC–MS Rt 3.13 min, m/z [M + H]+ 288.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H14ClN2O3S+ calcd 289.0408, found 289.0409.

    (E)-N-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)but-2-enamide (6h)

    It was prepared according to general procedure D (0.02 g, 12% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.16 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.5 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (s, 1H), 7.92 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.40 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 6.95 (dq, J = 13.8, 6.9 Hz, 1H), 5.95 (dt, J = 17.1, 4.7 Hz, 1H), 2.84 (s, 6H), 1.86 (dd, J = 6.9, 1.5 Hz, 3H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 164.5, 142.7, 137.7, 135.7, 132.8, 126.0, 125.0, 124.8, 122.7, 37.5, 37.5, 18.0; LC–MS Rt 3.19 min, m/z [M + H]+ 302.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C12H16ClN2O3S+ calcd 303.0565, found 303.0566.

    2-Chloro-5-((cyanomethyl)amino)-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (6i)

    The aniline intermediate 5 (1 equiv) was dissolved in THF (5 mL). Bromoacetonitrile (1.2 equiv) and DIPEA (3 equiv) were then added under stirring. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred under reflux overnight. The solvent was evaporated under vacuum, and the residue was redissolved in EtOAc. The organic layer was washed by H2O and brine and dried with MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a yellow oil (0.06 g, 32% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.38 (dd, J = 5.8, 4.4 Hz, 2H), 6.79 (dd, J = 8.6, 3.0 Hz, 1H), 4.14 (s, 2H), 2.89 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 144.1, 136.5, 133.1, 121.7, 117.6, 117.0, 116.1, 37.5, 37.5, 32.4; LC–MS Rt 3.14 min, m/z [M + H]+ 273.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13ClN3O2S+ calcd 274.0412, found 274.0417.

    (E)-2-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)ethene-1-sulfonyl Fluoride (6j)

    Ethenesulfonyl fluoride (3 equiv), palladium(II) acetate (10 mol %), copper(II) acetate (2 equiv), and lithium acetate (1.2 equiv) were dissolved in dry THF (5 mL) under N2 protection. The boronic acid intermediate 8 (1 equiv) was dissolved in dry THF (5 mL) under N2 protection in another flask, and the solution was added slowly into the mixture of reagents over a period of 30 min by a syringe. After the reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h, the solvent was evaporated under vacuum. The residue was redissolved in EtOAc. The organic layer was washed by H2O and brine and dried with MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 5% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a colorless solid (0.03 g, 7% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.26 (s, 1H), 7.79 (dd, J = 15.6, 0.6 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (d, J = 1.3 Hz, 2H), 6.98 (dd, J = 15.6, 2.5 Hz, 1H), 2.93 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 145.5 (d, JC–F = 2.5 Hz), 138.8, 136.3, 133.3, 133.0, 132.2, 130.1, 120.9 (d, JC–F = 29.1 Hz), 37.3, 37.3; LC–MS Rt 3.74 min, m/z [M + H]+ 327.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H12ClFNO4S2+ calcd 327.9875, found 327.9871.

    2-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)ethane-1-sulfonyl Fluoride (6k)

    Compound 6j (1 equiv) was dissolved in methanol (5 mL). 10% Pd/C (20% w/w) and triethylsilane (10 equiv) were added under nitrogen protection. Bubbling of hydrogen could be observed right away. After the bubbling stopped after about 5 min, the reaction was checked by TLC. 10% Pd/C (100% w/w × 2) and triethylsilane (100 equiv × 4) were added until full conversion was suggested by TLC. The reaction mixture was filtered by Celite and then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a colorless solid (0.004 g, 40% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.96 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.55–7.49 (m, 1H), 7.37 (dd, J = 8.2, 2.3 Hz, 1H), 3.70–3.63 (m, 2H), 3.30 (dd, J = 8.8, 6.7 Hz, 2H), 2.90 (s, 6H); LC–MS Rt 3.36 min, m/z [M + H]+ 329.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H14ClFNO4S2+ calcd 330.0031, found 330.0036.

    (4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)methanesulfonyl Fluoride (6l)

    It was prepared according to general procedure H (0.2 g, 69% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.07 (s, 1H), 7.52 (d, J = 1.3 Hz, 2H), 4.59 (s, 2H), 2.90 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 136.9, 136.6, 133.4, 132.6, 132.2, 132.1, 44.4, 37.4, 37.4; 19F NMR (CDCl3, 376 MHz): δ = −210.80 (s); LC–MS Rt 3.43 min, m/z [M + K]+ 355.1.

    3-(4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)propane-1-sulfonyl Fluoride (6m)

    It was prepared according to general procedure H (0.02 g, 64% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.90 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.31 (dt, J = 13.7, 6.8 Hz, 1H), 3.41–3.32 (m, 2H), 2.94–2.84 (m, 8H), 2.35–2.23 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 138.5, 136.7, 133.4, 132.5, 132.0, 130.7, 49.8 (d, JC–F = 17.3 Hz), 37.3, 37.3, 32.8, 24.7; LC–MS Rt 3.47 min, m/z [M + H]+ 343.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H16ClFNO4S2+ calcd 344.0188, found 344.0201.

    2-Chloro-N,N-dimethyl-5-(oxiran-2-ylmethyl)benzenesulfonamide (6n)

    The alkene intermediate 14 (1 equiv), 1H-pyrazole (0.25 equiv), and methyltrioxorhenium(VII) (0.06 equiv) were stirred together in DCM (5 mL) under N2 protection. Hydrogen peroxide (30 wt % solution in water, 4 equiv) was then added dropwise. After stirring overnight at rt, the reaction mixture was poured into water and the product was extracted into DCM (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined, washed with 2 M HCl solution and brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product, which was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a clean oil (0.03 g, 28% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.93 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.46 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.39 (dd, J = 8.1, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 3.15 (dtd, J = 6.4, 4.1, 2.6 Hz, 1H), 3.02–2.96 (m, 1H), 2.89 (s, 6H), 2.86–2.80 (m, 2H), 2.51 (dd, J = 4.8, 2.6 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 136.6, 136.1, 134.2, 132.6, 132.2, 130.5, 51.6, 46.6, 37.7, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 4.17 min, m/z [M + H]+ 275.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H15ClNO3S+ calcd 276.0456, found 276.0461.

    2-Chloro-N,N-dimethyl-5-(oxiran-2-yl)benzenesulfonamide (6o)

    Intermediate 19 (1 equiv) and potassium carbonate (2 equiv) were stirred together vigorously in acetone at rt for 24 h. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product, which was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 10–20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a yellow oil (0.02 g, 30% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.99 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.37 (ddd, J = 8.2, 2.2, 0.4 Hz, 1H), 3.91–3.88 (m, 1H), 3.19 (dd, J = 5.4, 4.0 Hz, 1H), 2.90 (s, 6H), 2.78 (dd, J = 5.4, 2.5 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 137.4, 136.5, 132.4, 131.8, 130.1, 129.6, 51.3, 51.2, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 3.41 min, m/z [M + H]+ 261.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13ClNO3S+ calcd 262.0299, found 262.0308.

    5-Bromo-2-chloro-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (7)

    To a stirred solution of 5 (1 equiv) in acetonitrile (5 mL) and hydrobromic acid (48% in H2O, 0.5 mL) at 0 °C was added sodium nitrite (1.2 equiv) dissolved in a minimum amount of water dropwise. The resulting mixture was stirred for 20 min at 0 °C and then cooled to −78 °C. Copper(I) bromide (1.4 equiv) was added at this temperature, and then the reaction mixture was allowed to warm to 0 °C and stirred for 1 h. The reaction mixture was then diluted with H2O, neutralized with 1 M NaOH solution, and extracted with EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined, washed with brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 10% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a colorless solid (0.19 g, 75% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.20 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.62–7.57 (m, 1H), 7.40–7.36 (m, 1H), 2.91 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 137.9, 136.4, 134.7, 133.4, 131.2, 120.6, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 3.38 min, m/z [M + H]+ 297.7; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C8H10BrClNO2S+ calcd 297.9299, found 297.9302.

    (4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)boronic Acid (8)

    To a stirred solution of 7 in dry THF (10 mL) at −78 °C under N2 protection was added 1.6 M methyllithium in Et2O (1.2 equiv). After 10 min, triisopropyl borate (5 equiv) was added, followed by the addition of 2.0 M n-BuLi in cyclohexane (2.2 equiv). After stirring at −78 °C for 2 h, the mixture was allowed to warm to rt and sat aq NH4Cl (10 mL) was cautiously added. The reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined, washed with H2O and brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with MeOH/DCM (1:200), affording the title compound as a clean oil (0.32 g, 34% yield). 1H NMR (methanol-d4, 400 MHz): δ = 8.34 (s, 1H), 7.90 (s, 1H), 7.59 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 1H), 2.87 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (methanol-d4, 101 MHz): δ = 138.8, 136.9, 134.8, 131.2, 36.3, 36.3; LC–MS Rt 3.02 min, m/z [M + H]+ 263.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C8H12BClNO4S+ calcd 264.0265, found 264.0267.

    4-Chloro-3-(chlorosulfonyl)benzoic Acid (9)

    To a round-bottom flask charged with 4-chlorobenzene acid (1 equiv) in an ice bath was added chlorosulfonic acid (30 mL). The reaction mixture was heated up to 150 °C and stirred overnight. After cooling down to rt, the reaction mixture was poured into ice and extracted with EtOAc (20 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined, washed with H2O and brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the title compound as an off-white solid (3.1 g, 95%). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 8.44 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.83 (dd, J = 8.2, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 166.9, 145.8, 135.9, 131.3, 131.1, 130.4, 129.3.

    4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)benzoic Acid (10)

    To a solution of 9 (1 equiv) in dry THF (5 mL) was added 2 M dimethylamine in THF (3 equiv). The reaction mixture was stirred at rt until the completion of reaction was indicated by TLC. The reaction mixture was then concentrated to dryness and partitioned between DCM and H2O. The pH was adjusted to 10 with 5 M NaOH solution, and the aqueous phase was isolated. The aqueous layer was acidified to pH 2 with 6 M HCl, and the mixture was stirred vigorously to give a white precipitate. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven under 50 °C overnight to give the title compound as an off-white solid (0.06 g, 53% yield). 1H NMR (methanol-d4, 400 MHz): δ = 8.61 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 8.20 (dd, J = 8.3, 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.76 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 2.91 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (methanol-d4, 101 MHz): δ = 165.9, 136.4, 136.4, 134.2, 132.6, 132.5, 130.1, 36.3, 36.3; LC–MS Rt 3.42 min, m/z [M + H]+ 263.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H11ClNO4S+ calcd 264.0092, found 264.0090.

    2-Chloro-5-(hydroxymethyl)-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (11)

    To a solution of 10 (1 equiv) in methanol (5 mL) was added concd H2SO4 (two drops), and the resulting mixture was refluxed overnight. After the reaction completed (monitored by TLC), the solvent was evaporated under vacuum and the residue was redissolved in EtOAc. The organic layer was washed by water and brine and dried over MgSO4. The resulting crude product (1 equiv) was dissolved in dry toluene at −78 °C, and 1 M diisobutylaluminum hydride in cyclohexane (2.5 equiv) was added. The reaction mixture was warmed to rt and stirred for 10 min and then was quenched with methanol. EtOAc was added to dilute the solution. The organic phase was washed by 0.5 M HCl solution (30 mL × 3), water (20 mL × 1), and brine (20 mL × 1) and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the title compound as an off-white solid (0.28 g, 89% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.04–7.94 (m, 1H), 7.49 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 2H), 4.73 (s, 2H), 2.88 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 140.4, 136.1, 132.2, 131.7, 131.0, 130.2, 63.7, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 3.60 min, m/z [M + H]+ 249.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H13ClNO3S+ calcd 250.0299, found 250.0293.

    5-(Bromomethyl)-2-chloro-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (12)

    To a solution of 11 (1 equiv) in dry DCM (5 mL) was added carbon tetrabromide (1.1 equiv). The reaction mixture was cooled to 0 °C, and triphenylphosphine (1.1 equiv) was added. The reaction was stirred vigorously and warmed to rt over 2 h. The reaction mixture was then poured into brine and extracted with DCM. The organic layers were combined and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a colorless solid (0.1 g, 93% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.00 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.47–7.41 (m, 2H), 4.40 (s, 2H), 2.83 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 137.3, 136.6, 133.9, 132.6, 132.5, 132.1, 37.4, 37.4, 30.9; LC–MS Rt 3.34 min, m/z [M + H]+ 311.7; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H12BrClNO2S+ calcd 311.9455, found 311.9458.

    (4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)methanesulfonyl Chloride (13)

    Benzyl bromide 12 (1 equiv) and sodium sulfite (1 equiv) were dissolved in a combination of acetone/water (v/v = 2:1). The resulting reaction mixture was stirred under reflux overnight. The solvent was evaporated in vacuo, and the resulting residue was redissolved in water and EtOAc. The aqueous layer was isolated, and the organic layer was washed with water (10 mL × 2). The aqueous layers were combined, and the pH was adjusted to 1. The sulfonic acid intermediate was then extracted into EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined, washed with brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude sulfonic acid intermediate. It was dissolved in thionyl chloride (20 mL), and a catalytic amount of DMF (two drops) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred overnight under reflux. The thionyl chloride was evaporated to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 10% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as an off-white solid (0.3 g, 23% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.07 (s, 1H), 7.52 (d, J = 1.3 Hz, 2H), 4.59 (s, 2H), 2.90 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 136.9, 136.6, 133.4, 132.6, 132.2, 132.1, 44.4, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 3.69 min, m/z [M – H]− 330.0; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H12Cl2NO4S2+ calcd 331.9579, found 331.9570.

    5-Allyl-2-chloro-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (14)

    To a solution of 12 (1 equiv) in dry toluene (5 mL) under N2 protection was added 3 mol % equiv of Pd(PPh3)4. After stirring for 15 min, tributyl(vinyl)stannane (1 equiv) diluted in dry toluene (3 mL) was added dropwise. The reaction mixture was stirred at 80 °C overnight. After filtering via Celite, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 5% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a pale-yellow oil (0.13 mg, 83% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.88 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.42 (dd, J = 12.0, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 7.30 (dd, J = 8.1, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 5.92 (ddt, J = 16.8, 10.1, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 5.11 (ddq, J = 20.2, 17.0, 1.5 Hz, 2H), 3.42 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.88 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 139.5, 135.9, 135.7, 133.7, 132.3, 132.1, 129.8, 117.3, 39.2, 37.3, 37.3; LC–MS Rt 4.36 min, m/z [M + H]+ 259.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H15ClNO2S+ calcd 260.0507, found 260.0511.

    2-Chloro-5-(3-hydroxypropyl)-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (15)

    To a solution of 14 (1 equiv) in dry THF (10 mL) at 0 °C was added 2 M borane dimethyl sulfide complex in THF (1 equiv). The mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 10 min and then at rt for 1 h under nitrogen protection. The nitrogen flow was stopped, and 15% NaOH solution (1.5 equiv) and 30% H2O2 solution (2 equiv) were successively added into the reaction mixture at 0 °C. The resulting mixture was stirred for 1 h at rt. The solvent was evaporated in vacuo, and the resulting residue was redissolved in a mixture of EtOAc and water. The product was extracted into the organic layer, which was washed with brine, dried by MgSO4, and purified by column chromatography, eluting with 10–35% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a clean oil (0.07 g, 14% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.88 (dd, J = 6.5, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.44–7.37 (m, 1H), 7.35–7.28 (m, 1H), 3.65 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 2.87 (s, 6H), 2.78–2.71 (m, 2H), 1.91–1.80 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 141.4, 135.7, 133.6, 132.1, 132.0, 129.5, 61.6, 37.3, 37.3, 33.8, 31.3; LC–MS Rt 3.23 min, m/z [M + H]+ 277.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H17ClNO3S+ calcd 278.0612, found 278.0619.

    4-Chloro-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)-N-methoxy-N-methylbenzamide (16)

    The carboxylic acid intermediate 10 (1 equiv) was dissolved in thionyl chloride (30 mL), and a catalytic amount of DMF (two drops) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred under reflux overnight. After cooling to rt, the thionyl chloride was evaporated under vacuum and the resulting residue was redissolved in DCM (10 mL). N,O-Dimethylhydroxylamine hydrochloride (1.3 equiv) and pyridine (3 equiv) were added at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was warmed to rt and stirred until the completion of reaction was detected by TLC. The reaction mixture was poured into 6 M HCl solution (10 mL), and the organic layer was extracted into EtOAc (20 mL). The organic layer was then washed with sat aq NaHCO3 and brine and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 35% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a clean oil (2.5 g, 92% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.37 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (dd, J = 8.2, 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 3.54 (s, 3H), 3.36 (d, J = 3.7 Hz, 3H), 2.89 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 167.2, 136.1, 134.5, 133.4, 132.9, 132.0, 132.0, 61.4, 37.4, 37.4, 23.8; LC–MS Rt 3.50 min, m/z [M + H]+ 306.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H16ClN2O4S+ calcd 307.0514, found 307.0520.

    5-Acetyl-2-chloro-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (17)

    The intermediate 16 (1 equiv) was dissolved in dry THF (10 mL) under N2 protection. Next, 2.46 M methylmagnesium bromide in Et2O (1.2 equiv) was added dropwise via a syringe at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was warmed to rt and stirred overnight. The reaction was quenched by sat aq NH4Cl (5 mL), and the organic layer was extracted to EtOAc (20 mL). The organic layer was then isolated, washed with H2O and brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as an off-white solid (1.8 g, 82% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.56 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 8.04 (dd, J = 8.3, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.61 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 2.91 (s, 6H), 2.62 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 195.5, 137.2, 135.7, 132.7, 132.6, 131.9, 131.9, 37.4, 37.4, 26.6; LC–MS Rt 3.22 min, m/z [M + H]+ 261.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13ClNO3S+ calcd 262.0299, found 262.0305.

    5-(2-Bromoacetyl)-2-chloro-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (18)

    The intermediate 17 (1 equiv) was dissolved in a combination of EtOAc/CHCl3 (v/v = 1:1). Copper(II) bromide (1.2 equiv) was added, and the resulting mixture was stirred vigorously under reflux overnight. After filtration, the filtrate was evaporated under vacuum. The resulting residue was redissolved in EtOAc and water. The organic layer was isolated, washed with water and brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 5–10% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a clean oil (0.12 g, 62% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.53 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 8.03 (dt, J = 8.3, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.60 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 4.37 (s, 2H), 2.86 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 189.3, 138.0, 137.3, 133.3, 133.0, 132.5, 132.4, 37.4, 37.4, 30.0; LC–MS Rt 4.12 min, m/z [M + H]+ 339.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H12BrClNO3S+ calcd 339.9404, found 339.9400.

    5-(2-Bromo-1-hydroxyethyl)-2-chloro-N,N-dimethylbenzenesulfonamide (19)

    To a solution of 18 (1 equiv) in methanol (5 mL) at 0 °C was added sodium borohydride (1 equiv). The reaction mixture was warmed to rt and stirred for 1 h. Then, 2 M HCl solution (10 mL) was added to quench the reaction. After methanol was evaporated under vacuum, the mixture was extracted by EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was then purified by column chromatography, eluting with 20% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a clean oil (0.08 g, 64% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 7.98 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.51–7.43 (m, 2H), 4.91 (dt, J = 9.2, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 3.57 (dt, J = 10.1, 5.0 Hz, 1H), 3.46 (dd, J = 10.6, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 2.82 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 139.9, 136.3, 132.4, 132.0, 131.0, 129.9, 72.3, 39.4, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 4.14 min, m/z [M + H]+ 341.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H14BrClNO3S+ calcd 341.9561, found 341.9568.

    2-Bromo-5-nitrobenzenesulfonic Acid (20a)

    It was prepared according to general procedure A (0.27 g, 98% yield). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 8.62 (s, 1H), 8.04 (s, 1H), 7.89 (d, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 136.0, 136.0, 127.7, 125.0, 123.8, 123.8; LC–MS Rt 1.87 min, m/z [M – H]− 279.7; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M – H]− for C6H3BrNO5S– calcd 279.8921, found 279.8936.

    2-Iodo-5-nitrobenzenesulfonic Acid (20b)

    2-Amino-5-nitrobenzenesulfonic acid (1 equiv) was dissolved in water (5 mL). To this solution cooled in an ice bath was added a solution of sodium nitrite (1.2 equiv) in water (2 mL) and concd HCl solution (2 mL). After stirring at 0 °C for 30 min, potassium iodide (1.2 equiv) was added to the mixture. The ice bath was removed, and the mixture was allowed to stir at rt for 1 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo to a smaller volume, and the solid was collected via filtration. The solid was dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 2 h, affording the title compound as a pale-yellow solid (0.24 g, 74% yield). 1H NMR (methanol-d4, 400 MHz): δ = 8.84 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.36–8.25 (m, 1H), 7.95 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.8 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (methanol-d4, 101 MHz): δ = 149.7, 147.5, 143.1, 124.4, 122.5, 100.5; LC–MS Rt 2.73 min, m/z [M – H]− 327.7; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + Na]+ for C6H4INO5SNa+ calcd 351.8747, found 351.8752.

    5-Nitro-2-(trifluoromethoxy)benzenesulfonic Acid (20c)

    To a mixture of 5-nitro-2-trifluoromethoxyaniline (1 equiv) in water (5 mL) was added concd HCl solution (1 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at rt for 1 h. A solution of sodium nitrite (1 equiv) in water (2 mL) was then added into the mixture at 0 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred for another 1 h at this temperature. This resulting mixture was then added to another solution of copper(II) chloride (0.1 equiv), sodium bisulfite (1.4 equiv), and concd HCl (1 mL) in water (5 mL) at 0 °C. The new reaction mixture was stirred under 0 °C for another 1 h. Then, the reaction mixture was warmed to rt and its pH was adjusted to 10 by 5 M NaOH solution. The resulting solution was washed by EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The aqueous layer was isolated, and its pH was adjusted to 2 by 6 M HCl solution. The resulting solution was extracted by EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the title compound as an orange oil (0.05 g, 17% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.79 (t, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 8.52–8.42 (m, 1H), 7.58–7.47 (m, 1H); 13C NMR (methanol-d4, 101 MHz): δ = 150.3 (d, J = 1.7 Hz), 146.1, 142.0, 128.3, 121.0, 120.6 (d, J = 2.3 Hz), 120.1 (q, J = 261.3 Hz); LC–MS Rt 2.90 min, m/z [M – H]− 285.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M – H]− for C7H3F3NO6S– calcd 285.9639, found 285.9651.

    2-Bromo-N,N-dimethyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (21a)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.12 g, 41% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.82 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.15 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.91–7.87 (m, 1H), 2.90 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 146.8, 140.4, 137.0, 127.7, 127.4, 126.9, 37.5, 37.5; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C8H10BrN2O4S+ calcd 308.9539, found 308.9538.

    2-Iodo-N,N-dimethyl-5-nitrobenzenesulfonamide (21b)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.14 g, 57% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.78 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 8.28–8.23 (m, 1H), 7.94 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 2.89 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 144.5, 144.5, 126.9, 126.9, 125.9, 125.9, 37.7, 37.7; LC–MS Rt 4.11 min, m/z [M + H]+ 356.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C8H10IN2O4S+ calcd 356.9400, found 356.9400.

    N,N-Dimethyl-5-nitro-2-(trifluoromethoxy)benzenesulfonamide (21c)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.01 g, 22% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.82 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 1H), 8.41 (dd, J = 9.1, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.51 (dq, J = 9.1, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 2.86 (d, J = 3.3 Hz, 7H); LC–MS Rt 3.38 min, m/z [M + H]+ 314.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H10F3N2O5S+ calcd 315.0257, found 315.0260.

    N,N-Dimethyl-4-nitro-[1,1′-biphenyl]-2-sulfonamide (21d)

    The intermediate 2a (1 equiv), phenylboronic acid (1.2 equiv), and Pd(dppf)Cl2 (20 mol %) were dissolved in DMF (3 mL) under N2 protection. Potassium carbonate (1.55 equiv) was dissolved in degassed water (1 M solution), and the aqueous solution was added by a syringe. The reaction mixture was degassed (×3) and put under a microwave at 120 °C for 1 h. Then, the reaction mixture was cooled to rt and filtered via Celite. The filtrate was collected and poured into water. The resulting mixture was extracted with EtOAc (10 mL × 3). The organic layers were combined, washed with H2O and brine, and dried over MgSO4. After filtration, the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography, eluting with 10% EtOAc/PB, affording the title compound as a colorless solid (0.03 g, 21% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.90 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 8.33 (dd, J = 8.3, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.44 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 7.41–7.36 (m, 3H), 7.35–7.32 (m, 2H), 2.31 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 147.8, 137.7, 134.1, 129.0, 129.0, 128.9, 128.0, 128.0, 128.0, 128.0, 126.3, 125.4, 36.1, 36.1; LC–MS Rt 3.45 min, m/z [M + H]+ 306.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C14H15N2O4S+ calcd 307.0747, found 307.0750.

    N,N-Dimethyl-5-nitro-2-(trifluoromethyl)benzenesulfonamide (21e)

    It was prepared according to general procedure I (0.08 g, 84% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.80 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 8.43 (dd, J = 8.6, 1.5 Hz, 1H), 8.06 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 2.89 (s, 7H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 149.5, 140.9, 133.3 (q, J = 34.2 Hz), 130.4 (q, J = 6.5 Hz), 126.8, 126.3, 121.6 (q, J = 275.1 Hz), 37.5 (2C); LC–MS Rt 3.49 min, m/z [M + H]+ 298.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C9H10F3N2O4S+ calcd 299.0308, found 299.0313.

    N-(4-Bromo-3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)phenyl)-2-chloroacetamide (22a)

    It was prepared according to general procedures C and D (0.01 g, 35% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.90 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 4.21 (s, 2H), 2.93 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 164.2, 138.6, 136.5, 136.4, 124.6, 123.3, 115.2, 42.8, 37.5, 37.5; LC–MS Rt 3.54 min, m/z [M + H]+ 354.7; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13BrClN2O3S+ calcd 354.9513, found 354.9514.

    2-Chloro-N-(3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)-4-iodophenyl)acetamide (22b)

    It was prepared according to general procedures C and D (0.003 g, 61% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.30 (s, 1H), 8.05 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.6 Hz, 1H), 4.14 (s, 2H), 2.86 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 167.7, 158.3, 139.8, 139.4, 125.2, 124.2, 122.6, 41.7, 37.4, 37.4; LC–MS Rt 4.21 min, m/z [M + H]+ 402.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H13ClIN2O3S+ calcd 402.9375, found 402.9382.

    2-Chloro-N-(3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)-4-(trifluoromethoxy)phenyl)acetamide (22c)

    It was prepared according to general procedures C and D (0.003 g, 32% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.39 (s, 1H), 8.12 (dd, J = 9.0, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.42 (dd, J = 9.0, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 4.22 (s, 2H), 2.88 (s, 6H); LC–MS Rt 3.31 min, m/z [M + H]+ 360.9; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H13ClF3N2O4S+ calcd 361.0231, found 361.0240.

    2-Chloro-N-(2-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)acetamide (22d)

    It was prepared according to general procedures C and D (0.02 g, 76% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.46 (s, 1H), 8.07 (dt, J = 6.9, 2.2 Hz, 2H), 7.44–7.35 (m, 5H), 7.33 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 4.24 (s, 2H), 2.35 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 164.3, 138.9, 138.2, 136.2, 133.8, 129.6, 129.6, 129.6, 127.9, 127.7, 127.7, 123.4, 121.5, 42.8, 36.0, 36.0; LC–MS Rt 3.38 min, m/z [M + H]+ 352.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C16H18ClN2O3S+ calcd 353.0721, found 353.0725.

    2-Chloro-N-(3-(N,N-dimethylsulfamoyl)-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)acetamide (22e)

    It was prepared according to general procedures C and D (0.03 g, 70% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.56 (s, 1H), 8.25 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 8.01–7.95 (m, 1H), 7.87 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 4.24 (s, 2H), 2.92 (s, 6H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 101 MHz): δ = 165.0, 140.5, 138.6, 129.8 (q, J = 6.5 Hz), 123.6 (q, J = 33.6 Hz), 122.4, 122.4 (q, J = 273.3 Hz), 122.0, 42.9, 37.4 (2C); LC–MS Rt 3.37 min, m/z [M + H]+ 344.8; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C11H13ClF3N2O3S+ calcd 345.0282, found 345.0289.

    4-((2-Iodo-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)morpholine (23)

    It was prepared according to general procedure B (0.37 g, 60% yield). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 8.58 (s, 1H), 8.49 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 8.12 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 3.64 (s, 4H), 3.23 (s, 4H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 147.9, 145.3, 141.7, 128.2, 126.0, 104.1, 66.0, 66.0, 45.9, 45.9; LC–MS Rt 3.13 min, m/z [M + H]+ 399.0; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C10H12IN2O5S+ calcd 398.9506, found 398.9516.

    4-((5-Nitro-2-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)sulfonyl)morpholine (24)

    It was prepared according to general procedure I (0.24 g, 85% yield). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ = 8.65 (d, J = 10.8 Hz, 2H), 8.35 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 3.66–3.63 (m, 4H), 3.23–3.20 (m, 4H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d6, 101 MHz): δ = 150.3, 138.6, 131.6 (q, JC–F = 7.3 Hz), 128.6, 127.3 (q, JC–F = 280.2 Hz), 126.8, 120.8, 66.1, 66.1, 46.0, 46.0; LC–MS Rt 3.18 min, m/z [M + H]+ 341.0.

    2-Chloro-N-(3-(morpholinosulfonyl)-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)acetamide (25)

    It was prepared according to general procedures C and D (0.13 g, 55% yield). 1H NMR (methanol-d4, 400 MHz): δ = 8.45 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.92–7.84 (m, 2H), 4.19 (s, 2H), 3.74–3.68 (m, 4H), 3.29–3.23 (m, 4H); 13C NMR (methanol-d4, 101 MHz): δ = 166.5, 141.8, 137.7, 137.7, 129.5 (q, JC–F = 6.5 Hz), 122.7 (q, JC–F = 151.5 Hz), 122.5, 122.0, 66.3, 66.3, 45.8, 45.8, 42.7; LC–MS Rt 3.17 min, m/z [M + H]+ 387.0; HRMS (ESI): m/z [M + H]+ for C13H15ClF3N2O4S+ calcd 387.0388, found 387.0390.

    Interference Compounds

    All final compounds have been examined for the presence of substructures classified as pan assay interference compounds (PAINS) using a KNIME workflow.(64,65)

    Biological Assays

    4-NPG Assay

    GSTO1-1 activity as IC50 values was determined using S-(4-nitrophenacyl)glutathione as a substrate.(26) A reaction mix (930 μL containing 100 mM Tris [pH 8.0], 1.5 mM EDTA, and 10 mM 2-mercaptoethanol) was combined with 10 μL of 0.1 mg/mL recombinant GSTO1-1 (expressed in Escherichia coli and purified by two separate methods(66)) and 10 μL of the test compound in DMSO (0–1250 nM final concentration) and incubated at 37 °C for 2 min. After incubation, the reaction was initiated by the addition of 50 μL of 10 mM 4-NPG, and the decrease in absorbance at 305 nm was recorded. The percent GSTO1-1 activity remaining was determined by measuring the initial linear rate relative to the control without the compound. An IC50 value was determined from a dose–response curve from three replicates at five inhibitor concentrations using Prism software (GraphPad).

    kinact/KI Measurement

    The kinact and KI values were determined with an adaptation of the 4-NPG assay. A reaction mix (930 μL containing 100 mM Tris [pH 8.0], 1.5 mM EDTA, and 10 mM 2-mercaptoethanol) was combined with 10 μL of 0.1 mg/mL GSTO1-1 and 10 μL of the test compound (50–1500 nM final concentration) and incubated at 37 °C for either 1, 2, 4, or 6 min. After the incubation, the reaction was initiated by the addition of 50 μL of 10 mM 4-NPG, and the decrease in absorbance at 305 nm was recorded to determine the reaction rate. Each compound was tested in triplicate at each concentration and incubation time point. A plot of ln(Et/E0) versus time (min–1) was made, and −kobs was the slope, according to the equation Et/E0 = e–(kobs × t), where E0 and Et refer to GSTO1-1 activity at times zero and t, respectively. According to the equation kobs/kinact = [I]/(KI + [I]), where [I] refers to the inhibitor concentration, a plot of 1/kobs versus 1/[I] was made, yielding KI/kinact as the slope and 1/kinact as the Y intercept.

    Cell Assay

    Freshly prepared bone marrow-derived macrophages were seeded at 1 × 104 cells/well on 96-well plates in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (v/v) and incubated overnight at 37 °C in 5% CO2. The cells were initially treated with 200 ng/mL LPS for 3 h. After LPS stimulation, the media was removed and the cells were washed with PBS and the media replaced with serum-free DMEM with GSTO1-1 inhibitors at 5 μM final concentrations. After 1 h, media and inhibitors were removed and the cells were washed with PBS. The cells were then treated with 5 mM ATP in DMEM for 1 h for NLRP3 inflammasome activation. Subsequently, 100 μL of the supernatant was collected and stored for cytokine quantification. IL-1β was measured using an R&D systems Quantitative ELISA kit (cat#MLB00C). The amount of IL-1β released is calculated relative (%) to the release from cells incubated without a GSTO1-1 inhibitor.

    Structural Biology

    Human GSTO1-1 was expressed and purified as previously described.(67,68) Protein at ∼10 mg/mL in 20 mM Tris pH 8.0, 60 mM NaCl, and 1 mM DTT was crystallized by the hanging drop vapor diffusion method. To the reservoirs of 24-well VDX plates (Hampton Research, CA) was added 1 mL of the precipitant solution (1.7–2.2 M (NH4)2SO4, 0.2 M sodium potassium tartrate, 0.75 mM ZnSO4, 17 mM citric acid). On siliconized coverslips, 2 μL of protein was mixed with 2 μL of reservoir solution prior to suspension over the reservoir. Trays were stored at 4 °C. Crystals appeared as hexagonal prisms and grew to maximum size within 2 weeks. The solid compound was seeded into a drop containing crystals and allowed to equilibrate for a minimum of 1 month. Crystals were transferred stepwise to cryoprotectant solutions comprising the reservoir solution and 10–20% glycerol prior to flash-cooling to 100 K. X-ray data were collected at the Australian synchrotron beamline MX1. Diffraction data was integrated with MOSFLM and scaled with AIMLESS.(69,70) The structure was solved by PHASER, using the structure of GSTO1-1 in complex with GSH (PDB ID 1EEM). Iterative cycles of model building and refinement were performed using PHENIX, COOT, and REFMAC.(71−73) Electron density in 2mFo – DFc and mFo – DFc electron density maps was interpreted as a bound compound and included in the model. X-ray data and model quality are given in Table S1.

    • Author Contributions

      Y.X. performed synthetic chemistry and wrote the manuscript. P.T., M.R., M.G.C., and P.G.B. performed biological assays. A.J.O. performed crystallographic analysis. Y.N. resynthesized some final compounds. M.E.C., J.M.S., J.L.D., and M.A.W. were involved in the ALARM NMR test. P.T., A.J.O., G.S.D., J.L.D., M.G.C., P.G.B., and J.B.B. contributed to manuscript preparation.

      The authors declare no competing financial interest.

    a La assay to detect reactive molecules by nuclear magnetic resonance

    AMD

    age-related macular degeneration

    BMDM

    bone marrow-derived macrophages

    Cmax

    maximum plasma concentration

    DIPEA

    N,N-diisopropylethylamine

    Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium

    1,1′-bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene

    glutathione

    human Lupus antigen

    interleukin

    IS

    internal standard

    kinact

    rate of enzyme inactivation

    lower limit of quantitation

    NIMA-related kinase 7

    S-(4-nitrophenacyl)glutathione

    pan assay interference compounds

      Xie, Y.; Dahlin, J. L.; Oakley, A. J.; Casarotto, M. G.; Board, P. G.; Baell, J. B. Reviewing hit discovery literature for difficult targets: glutathione transferase Omega-1 as an example. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 7448– 7470,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.8b00318
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Reviewing Hit Discovery Literature for Difficult Targets: Glutathione Transferase Omega-1 as an Example
      Xie, Yiyue; Dahlin, Jayme L.; Oakley, Aaron J.; Casarotto, Marco G.; Board, Philip G.; Baell, Jonathan B.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (17), 7448-7470CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Early stage drug discovery reporting on relatively new or difficult targets is often assocd. with insufficient hit triage. Literature reviews of such targets seldom delve into the detail required to critically analyze the assocd. screening hits reported. Here we take the enzyme glutathione transferase omega-1 (GSTO1-1) as an example of a relatively difficult target and review the assocd. literature involving small-mol. inhibitors. As part of this process we deliberately pay closer-than-usual attention to assay interference and hit quality aspects. We believe this Perspective will be a useful guide for future development of GSTO1-1 inhibitors, as well serving as a template for future review formats of new or difficult targets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXnsFSgsbY%253D&md5=31037759dc901cb8b1f5a78877fa237c
    2. 2
      Menon, D.; Coll, R.; O’Neill, L. A.; Board, P. G. Glutathione transferase omega 1 is required for the lipopolysaccharide-stimulated induction of NADPH oxidase 1 and the production of reactive oxygen species in macrophages. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2014, 73, 318– 327,  DOI: 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2014.05.020
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Glutathione transferase Omega 1 is required for the lipopolysaccharide-stimulated induction of NADPH oxidase 1 and the production of reactive oxygen species in macrophages
      Menon, Deepthi; Coll, Rebecca; O'Neill, Luke A. J.; Board, Philip G.
      Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2014), 73 (), 318-327CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) stimulation of macrophages and inflammation via the Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) signaling pathway through NF-κB generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) and proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-1β, IL-6, and TNFα. Because glutathione transferase Omega 1-1 (GSTO1-1) can catalyze redox reactions such as the deglutathionylation of proteins and has also been implicated in the release of IL-1β the authors investigated its role in the development of LPS-mediated inflammation. The data show that shRNA knockdown of GSTO1-1 in macrophage-like J774.1A cells blocks the expression of NADPH oxidase 1 and the generation of ROS after LPS stimulation. Similar results were obtained with a GSTO1-1 inhibitor. To maintain high ROS levels during an inflammatory response, LPS stimulation causes the suppression of enzymes such as catalase and glutathione peroxidase that protect against oxidative stress. The knockdown of GSTO1-1 also attenuates this response. The data indicate that GSTO1-1 needs to be catalytically active and mediates its effects on the LPS/TLR4 inflammatory pathway upstream of NF-κB. These data suggest that GSTO1-1 is a novel target for anti-inflammatory intervention.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1SksrvE&md5=c7d253152bfa0c535a89f798a47a6f46
    3. 3
      Hughes, M. M.; Hooftman, A.; Angiari, S.; Tummala, P.; Zaslona, Z.; Runtsch, M.; Mc-Dermott, E. P.; Diskin, C.; Rooke, M.; Takahashi, S.; Sundararaj, S.; Casarotto, M. G.; Dahlstrom, J. E.; Corr, S. C.; Sutton, C. E.; McGettrick, A. F.; Mills, K. H. G.; Neamati, N.; Xie, Y.; Baell, J. B.; Preston, R. J. S.; Board, P. G.; O’Neill, L. A. J. Glutathione transferase Omega-1 regulates NLRP3 inflammasome activation through NEK7 deglutathionylation. Cell Rep. 2019, 29, 151– 161,  DOI: 10.1016/j.celrep.2019.08.072
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Glutathione Transferase Omega-1 Regulates NLRP3 Inflammasome Activation through NEK7 Deglutathionylation
      Hughes, Mark M.; Hooftman, Alexander; Angiari, Stefano; Tummala, Padmaja; Zaslona, Zbigniew; Runtsch, Marah C.; McGettrick, Anne F.; Sutton, Caroline E.; Diskin, Ciana; Rooke, Melissa; Takahashi, Shuhei; Sundararaj, Srinivasan; Casarotto, Marco G.; Dahlstrom, Jane E.; Palsson-McDermott, Eva M.; Corr, Sinead C.; Mills, Kingston H. G.; Preston, Roger J. S.; Neamati, Nouri; Xie, Yiyue; Baell, Jonathan B.; Board, Philip G.; O'Neill, Luke A. J.
      Cell Reports (2019), 29 (1), 151-161.e5CODEN: CREED8; ISSN:2211-1247. (Cell Press)
      The NLRP3 inflammasome is a cytosolic complex sensing phagocytosed material and various damage-assocd. mol. patterns, triggering prodn. of the pro-inflammatory cytokines interleukin-1 beta (IL)-1β and IL-18 and promoting pyroptosis. Here, we characterize glutathione transferase omega 1-1 (GSTO1-1), a constitutive deglutathionylating enzyme, as a regulator of the NLRP3 inflammasome. Using a small mol. inhibitor of GSTO1-1 termed C1-27, endogenous GSTO1-1 knockdown, and GSTO1-1-/- mice, we report that GSTO1-1 is involved in NLRP3 inflammasome activation. Mechanistically, GSTO1-1 deglutathionylates cysteine 253 in NIMA related kinase 7 (NEK7) to promote NLRP3 activation. We therefore identify GSTO1-1 as an NLRP3 inflammasome regulator, which has potential as a drug target to limit NLRP3-mediated inflammation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhvFSqtrjM&md5=0c3de58791a8b626ec0b2204736f5a3c
    4. 4
      Menon, D.; Innes, A.; Oakley, A. J.; Dahlstrom, J. E.; Jensen, L. M.; Brustle, A.; Tummala, P.; Rooke, M.; Casarotto, M. G.; Baell, J. B.; Nguyen, N.; Xie, Y.; Cuellar, M.; Strasser, J.; Dahlin, J. L.; Walters, M. A.; Burgio, G.; O’Neill, L. A. J.; Board, P. G. GSTO1-1 plays a pro-inflammatory role in models of inflammation, colitis and obesity. Sci. Rep. 2017, 7, 17832  DOI: 10.1038/s41598-017-17861-6
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      GSTO1-1 plays a pro-inflammatory role in models of inflammation, colitis and obesity
      Menon Deepthi; Innes Ashlee; Jensen Lora M; Brustle Anne; Tummala Padmaja; Rooke Melissa; Casarotto Marco G; Burgio Gaetan; Board Philip G; Menon Deepthi; O'Neill Luke A J; Oakley Aaron J; Dahlstrom Jane E; Baell Jonathan B; Nguyen Nghi; Xie Yiyue; Baell Jonathan B; Cuellar Matthew; Strasser Jessica; Walters Michael A; Dahlin Jayme L
      Scientific reports (2017), 7 (1), 17832 ISSN:.
      Glutathione transferase Omega 1 (GSTO1-1) is an atypical GST reported to play a pro-inflammatory role in response to LPS. Here we show that genetic knockout of Gsto1 alters the response of mice to three distinct inflammatory disease models. GSTO1-1 deficiency ameliorates the inflammatory response stimulated by LPS and attenuates the inflammatory impact of a high fat diet on glucose tolerance and insulin resistance. In contrast, GSTO1-1 deficient mice show a more severe inflammatory response and increased escape of bacteria from the colon into the lymphatic system in a dextran sodium sulfate mediated model of inflammatory bowel disease. These responses are similar to those of TLR4 and MyD88 deficient mice in these models and confirm that GSTO1-1 is critical for a TLR4-like pro-inflammatory response in vivo. In wild-type mice, we show that a small molecule inhibitor that covalently binds in the active site of GSTO1-1 can be used to ameliorate the inflammatory response to LPS. Our findings demonstrate the potential therapeutic utility of GSTO1-1 inhibitors in the modulation of inflammation and suggest their possible application in the treatment of a range of inflammatory conditions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1Mzjtlehtg%253D%253D&md5=360b424b4c6c9409e7c2836559f61ff1

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Xu, Jin; Lu, Liqun; Li, Lanfang
      Acta Biochimica et Biophysica Sinica (2016), 48 (10), 966-968CODEN: ABBSC2; ISSN:1672-9145. (ABBS Editorial Office)
      A review discussing NEK7 a novel promising therapy target for NLRP3-related inflammatory diseases.

    6. 6
      Mangan, M. S. J.; Olhava, E. J.; Roush, W. R.; Seidel, H. M.; Glick, G. D.; Latz, E. Targeting the NLRP3 inflammasome in inflammatory diseases. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2018, 17, 588– 606,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd.2018.97
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Targeting the NLRP3 inflammasome in inflammatory diseases
      Mangan, Matthew S. J.; Olhava, Edward J.; Roush, William R.; Seidel, H. Martin; Glick, Gary D.; Latz, Eicke
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2018), 17 (8), 588-606CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      Danger signals are a hallmark of many common inflammatory diseases, and these stimuli can function to activate the cytosolic innate immune signalling receptor NLRP3 (NOD-, LRR- and pyrin domain-contg. 3). Once activated, NLRP3 nucleates the assembly of an inflammasome, leading to caspase 1-mediated proteolytic activation of the interleukin-1β (IL-1β) family of cytokines, and induces an inflammatory, pyroptotic cell death. Pharmacol. inhibition of NLRP3 activation results in potent therapeutic effects in a wide variety of rodent models of inflammatory diseases, effects that are mirrored by genetic ablation of NLRP3. Although these findings highlight the potential of NLRP3 as a drug target, an understanding of NLRP3 structure and activation mechanisms is incomplete, which has hampered the discovery and development of novel therapeutics against this target. Here, we review recent advances in our understanding of NLRP3 activation and regulation, highlight the evolving landscape of NLRP3 modulators and discuss opportunities for pharmacol. targeting NLRP3 with novel small mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtlGlt7bM&md5=57b064477ea056dc859f6c90c4d00c36
    7. 7
      Toldo, S.; Abbate, A. The NLRP3 inflammasome in acute myocardial infarction. Nat. Rev. Cardiol. 2018, 15, 203– 214,  DOI: 10.1038/nrcardio.2017.161
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      The NLRP3 inflammasome in acute myocardial infarction
      Toldo, Stefano; Abbate, Antonio
      Nature Reviews Cardiology (2018), 15 (4), 203-214CODEN: NRCAE6; ISSN:1759-5002. (Nature Research)
      The heart is extremely sensitive to ischemic injury. During an acute myocardial infarction (AMI) event, the injury is initially caused by reduced blood supply to the tissues, which is then further exacerbated by an intense and highly specific inflammatory response that occurs during reperfusion. Numerous studies have highlighted the central role of the NACHT, LRR, and PYD domains-contg. protein 3 (NLRP3) inflammasome in this process. The inflammasome, an integral part of the innate immune system, is a macromol. protein complex that finely regulates the activation of caspase 1 and the prodn. and secretion of powerful pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1β and IL-18. In this Review, we summarize evidence supporting the therapeutic value of NLRP3 inflammasome-targeted strategies in exptl. models, and the data supporting the role of the NLRP3 inflammasome in AMI and its consequences on adverse cardiac remodelling, cytokine-mediated systolic dysfunction, and heart failure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvVWmsLnM&md5=ddc79b74012013d719412bd8feaec988
    8. 8
      Li, Y. J.; Oliveira, S. A.; Xu, P.; Martin, E. R.; Stenger, J. E.; Scherzer, C. R.; Hauser, M. A.; Scott, W. K.; Small, G. W.; Nance, M. A.; Watts, R. L.; Hubble, J. P.; Koller, W. C.; Pahwa, R.; Stern, M. B.; Hiner, B. C.; Jankovic, J.; Goetz, C. G.; Mastaglia, F.; Middleton, L. T.; Roses, A. D.; Saunders, A. M.; Schmechel, D. E.; Gullans, S. R.; Haines, J. L.; Gilbert, J. R.; Vance, J. M.; Pericak-Vance, M. A. Glutathione S-transferase omega-1 modifies age-at-onset of Alzheimer disease and Parkinson disease. Hum. Mol. Genet. 2003, 12, 3259– 3267,  DOI: 10.1093/hmg/ddg357
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Glutathione S-transferase omega-1 modifies age-at-onset of Alzheimer disease and Parkinson disease
      Li, Yi-Ju; Oliveira, Sofia A.; Xu, Puting; Martin, Eden R.; Stenger, Judith E.; Scherzer, Clemens R.; Hauser, Michael A.; Scott, William K.; Small, Gary W.; Nance, Martha A.; Watts, Ray L.; Hubble, Jean P.; Koller, William C.; Pahwa, Rajesh; Stern, Mathew B.; Hiner, Bradley C.; Jankovic, Joseph; Goetz, Christopher G.; Mastaglia, Frank; Middleton, Lefkos T.; Roses, Allen D.; Saunders, Ann M.; Schmechel, Donald E.; Gullans, Steven R.; Haines, Jonathan L.; Gilbert, John R.; Vance, Jeffery M.; Pericak-Vance, Margaret A.
      Human Molecular Genetics (2003), 12 (24), 3259-3267CODEN: HMGEE5; ISSN:0964-6906. (Oxford University Press)
      We previously reported genetic linkage of loci controlling age-at-onset in Alzheimer disease (AD) and Parkinson's disease (PD) to a 15 cM region on chromosome 10q. Given the large no. of genes in this initial starting region, we applied the process of genomic convergence' to prioritize and reduce the no. of candidate genes for further anal. As our second convergence factor we performed gene expression studies on hippocampus obtained from AD patients and controls. Anal. revealed that four of the genes [stearoyl-CoA desaturase; NADH-ubiquinone oxidoreductase 1 beta subcomplex 8; protease, serine 11; and glutathione S-transferase, omega-1 (GSTO1)] were significantly different in their expression between AD and controls and mapped to the 10q age-at-onset linkage region, the first convergence factor. Using 2814 samples from our AD dataset (1773 AD patients) and 1362 samples from our PD dataset (635 PD patients), allelic assocn. studies for age-at-onset effects in AD and PD revealed no assocn. for three of the candidates, but a significant assocn. was found for GSTO1 (P=0.007) and a second transcribed member of the GST omega class, GSTO2 (P=0.005), located next to GSTO1. The functions of GSTO1 and GSTO2 are not well understood, but recent data suggest that GSTO1 maybe involved in the post-translational modification of the inflammatory cytokine interleukin-1β. This is provocative given reports of the possible role of inflammation in these two neurodegenerative disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpsl2mtLk%253D&md5=083792adfeb183d9f4a5bedddbe5d543
    9. 9
      Capurso, C.; Panza, F.; Seripa, D.; Frisardi, V.; Imbimbo, B. P.; Verdile, G.; Vendemiale, G.; Pilotto, A.; Solfrizzi, V. Polymorphisms in glutathione S-transferase omega-1 gene and increased risk of sporadic Alzheimer disease. Rejuvenation Res. 2010, 13, 645– 652,  DOI: 10.1089/rej.2010.1052
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Polymorphisms in Glutathione S-Transferase Omega-1 Gene and Increased Risk of Sporadic Alzheimer Disease
      Capurso, Cristiano; Panza, Francesco; Seripa, Davide; Frisardi, Vincenza; Imbimbo, Bruno P.; Verdile, Gerardo; Vendemiale, Gianluigi; Pilotto, Alberto; Solfrizzi, Vincenzo
      Rejuvenation Research (2010), 13 (6), 645-652CODEN: RREEC2; ISSN:1549-1684. (Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.)
      Previous studies examg. the assocn. between the glutathione S-transferase omega-1 (GSTO1) single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and Alzheimer disease (AD) have yielded conflicting results. Furthermore, an effect of GSTO1 rs4925 on the age-at-onset (AAO) of AD was found in different studies on sporadic and familial AD cases, but with contrasting findings. A total sample of 103 AD patients, and 157 age- and sex-matched unrelated caregivers from Apulia, southern Italy, were genotyped for the apolipoprotein E (APOE) polymorphism and the GSTO1 rs4925 and rs1804834 SNPs. Furthermore, we performed a haplotype anal. on these two SNPs on the GSTO1 locus and evaluated the possibility of interaction with APOE. Significant differences were obsd. in rs4925 genotype distribution between AD patients and age- and sex-matched healthy controls. Both the C/A (odds ratio [OR] = 3.116; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.749-5.550) and the A/A (OR = 10.802; 95% CI, 3.605-32.128) genotypes resulted in an assocn. with AD. A higher frequency of the allele A was obsd. in AD patients than in age- and sex-matched controls (OR = 3.789; 95% CI, 2.442-5.878). No significant differences were obsd. in the rs1804834 genotype or allele frequencies between AD patients and controls. No significant influence of the GSTO1 genotypes on the AAO was obsd. No significant interaction was found among the GSTO1 SNPs and APOE. In both AD and controls, no important linkage disequil. (LD) was obsd. among the markers investigated. Whereas the C-A haplotype appeared to be protective against AD (OR = 0.303; 95% CI, 0.204-0.451), the A-A haplotype appeared to be at increased risk for AD (OR = 4.014,; 95% CI, 2.528-6.382). Our findings supported a role of the GSTO1 rs4925 SNP in the risk of sporadic AD in southern Italy, suggesting that this and other variants of the GSTO1 gene could be implicated in AD pathogenesis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXlt12htA%253D%253D&md5=f6974550f734c8aded48154ae5e23bfc
    10. 10
      Fernando, N.; Wooff, Y.; Aggio-Bruce, R.; Chu-Tan, J. A.; Jiao, H. H.; Dietrich, C.; Rutar, M.; Rooke, M.; Menon, D.; Eells, J. T.; Valter, K.; Board, P. G.; Provis, J.; Natoli, R. Photoreceptor survival is regulated by GSTO1-1 in the degenerating retina. Invest. Ophthalmol. Visual Sci. 2018, 59, 4362– 4374,  DOI: 10.1167/iovs.18-24627
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Photoreceptor survival is regulated by GSTO1-1 in the degenerating retina
      Fernando, Nilisha; Wooff, Yvette; Aggio-Bruce, Riemke; Chu-Tan, Joshua A.; Jiao, Haihan; Dietrich, Catherine; Rutar, Matt; Rooke, Melissa; Menon, Deepthi; Eells, Janis T.; Valter, Krisztina; Board, Philip G.; Provis, Jan; Natoli, Riccardo
      Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science (2018), 59 (11), 4362-4374CODEN: IOVSDA; ISSN:1552-5783. (Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology)
      Purpose: Glutathione-S-transferase omega 1-1 (GSTO1-1) is a cytosolic glutathione transferase enzyme, involved in glutathionylation, toll-like receptor signaling, and calcium channel regulation. GSTO1-1 dysregulation has been implicated in oxidative stress and inflammation, and contributes to the pathogenesis of several diseases and neurol. disorders; however, its role in retinal degenerations is unknown. The aim of this study was to investigate the role of GSTO1-1 in modulating oxidative stress and consequent inflammation in the normal and degenerating retina. Methods: The role of GSTO1-1 in retinal degenerations was explored by using Gsto1-/- mice in a model of retinal degeneration. The expression and localization of GSTO1-1 were investigated with immunohistochem. and Western blot. Changes in the expression of inflammatory (Ccl2, Il-1β, and C3) and oxidative stress (Nox1, Sod2, Gpx3, Hmox1, Nrf2, and Nqo1) genes were investigated via quant. real-time polymerase chain reaction. Retinal function in Gsto1-/- mice was investigated by using electroretinog. Results: GSTO1-1 was localized to the inner segment of cone photoreceptors in the retina. Gsto1-/- photo-oxidative damage (PD) mice had decreased photoreceptor cell death as well as decreased expression of inflammatory (Ccl2, Il-1β, and C3) markers and oxidative stress marker Nqo1. Further, retinal function in the Gsto1-/- PD mice was increased as compared to wild-type PD mice. Conclusions: These results indicate that GSTO1-1 is required for inflammatory-mediated photoreceptor death in retinal degenerations. Targeting GSTO1-1 may be a useful strategy to reduce oxidative stress and inflammation and ameliorate photoreceptor loss, slowing the progression of retinal degenerations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtVaiurnF&md5=cbfcab97cb7554f3d4b93144ae3e55ee
    11. 11
      Djukic, T.; Simic, T.; Pljesa-Ercegovac, M.; Matic, M.; Suvakov, S.; Coric, V.; Dragicevic, D.; Savic-Radojevic, A. Upregulated glutathione transferase omega-1 correlates with progression of urinary bladder carcinoma. Redox Rep. 2017, 22, 486– 492,  DOI: 10.1080/13510002.2017.1299909
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Upregulated glutathione transferase omega-1 correlates with progression of urinary bladder carcinoma
      Djukic, Tatjana; Simic, Tatjana; Pljesa-Ercegovac, Marija; Matic, Marija; Suvakov, Sonja; Coric, Vesna; Dragicevic, Dejan; Savic-Radojevic, Ana
      Redox Report (2017), 22 (6), 486-492CODEN: RDRPE4; ISSN:1351-0002. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      : Newly discovered glutathione transferase omega 1 (GSTO1-1) plays an important role in the glutathionylation cycle, a significant mechanism of protein function regulation. GSTO1-1 expression pattern has not been studied in transitional cell carcinoma (TCC), as yet.: A total of 56 TCC tumor and corresponding non-tumor specimens were investigated. Glutathione content and thioltransferase activity were measured spectrophotometrically. Protein-glutathione mixed disulfides were measured fluorimetrically. GSTO1-1 expression was detd. by immunoblot and qPCR. Immunopptn. with GSTO1-1 antibody was followed by immunoblot using anti-GSTO1, GSTP1, c-Jun, JNK, Akt, phospho-Akt, and ASK1 antibody, while for the total S-glutathionylation levels non-reducing electrophoresis was performed.: The contents of reduced glutathione and thioltransferase activity were significantly increased in tumor compared to non-tumor tissue. The increased GSTO1 expression in tumor tissue showed clear correlation with grade and stage. However, decreased total protein glutathionylation level in tumor compared to non-tumor samples was found. Immunopptn. has shown an assocn. of GSTO1-1 with GSTP1, Akt, phospho-Akt, and ASK1 proteins.: GSTO1 deglutathionylase activity suggests its potential important role in redox perturbations present in TCC. Increased GSTO1-1 expression might contribute to TCC development and/or progression supporting the notion that GSTO1-1 may be a promising novel cancer target.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktlKnurY%253D&md5=75be44b48cbd1c6e2d24b1061776b6c3

      Li, Y.; Zhang, Q.; Peng, B.; Shao, Q.; Qian, W.; Zhang, J. Y. Identification of glutathione S-transferase omega 1 (GSTO1) protein as a novel tumor-associated antigen and its autoantibody in human esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. Tumor Biol. 2014, 35, 10871– 10877,  DOI: 10.1007/s13277-014-2394-y
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Identification of glutathione S-transferase omega 1 (GSTO1) protein as a novel tumor-associated antigen and its autoantibody in human esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
      Li, Yang; Zhang, Qi; Peng, Bo; Shao, Qing; Qian, Wei; Zhang, Jian-Ying
      Tumor Biology (2014), 35 (11), 10871-10877CODEN: TUMBEA; ISSN:1010-4283. (Springer)
      Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is the main form of esophageal malignancy. The approach for early diagnosis of this malignancy is very limited. In the present study, we first evaluated glutathione S-transferase omega 1 (GSTO1), a protein related to metab., as a tumor-assocd. antigen in ESCC, and we also evaluated its autoantibody as a potential biomarker in early detection of ESCC. First, immunohistochem. (IHC) anal. of GSTO1 protein expression in esophageal tissues showed that the percentage of pos. staining of GSTO1 in ESCC tissues was 87.5 % while there was no pos. staining in adjacent tissues or normal tissues, indicating that overexpression of GSTO1 is closely related to ESCC. Then, ELISA (ELISA) showed that the frequency of detectable autoantibody against GSTO1 in patients' sera totals 44.8 %. In contrast, the frequency of detectable autoantibody was only 6.7 % in normal human sera (p < 0.01). To further evaluate our ELISA results, western blotting and immunofluorescence assay were also performed. The results were consistent with the data from ELISA. In conclusion, the current study has demonstrated that GSTO1 protein is overexpressed in ESCC and can induce a detectable autoantibody response, which may serve as a potential biomarker in the early detection of ESCC.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht1KltL3N&md5=f6eb465217f07355a9c502225b775442

      Chen, J. H.; Ni, R. Z.; Xiao, M. B.; Guo, J. G.; Zhou, J. W. Comparative proteomic analysis of differentially expressed proteins in human pancreatic cancer tissue. Hepatobiliary Pancreatic Dis. Int. 2009, 8, 193– 200
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Comparative proteomic analysis of differentially expressed proteins in human pancreatic cancer tissue
      Chen, Jian-Hua; Ni, Run-Zhou; Xiao, Ming-Bing; Guo, Ji-Guang; Zhou, Jia-Wei
      Hepatobiliary & Pancreatic Diseases International (2009), 8 (2), 193-200CODEN: HPDIAJ; ISSN:1499-3872. (First Affiliated Hospital, Zhejiang University School of Medicine)
      Pancreatic cancer is one of the most common malignant tumors. Early diagnosis of pancreatic cancer is difficult because of the latent onset and lack of good biomarkers. This study aimed to look for and identify differentially expressed proteins in tissues of pancreatic cancer and adjacent noncancerous tissues by proteomic approaches so as to provide information about possible pancreatic cancer markers and therapeutic targets. Proteins extd. from 3 paired adjacent noncancerous and cancerous pancreatic tissue specimens were sepd. by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE). The protein spots exhibiting statistical alternations between the two groups through computerized image anal. were then identified by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS). In addn., Western blotting and immunohistochem. were performed to verify the expression of certain candidate proteins. Twelve proteins were significantly upregulated and 4 were downregulated between cancerous and paired adjacent noncancerous pancreatic tissues. Several proteins (S100A11, Ig gamma-1 chain C region, GSTO1 and peroxiredoxin 4) were found for the first time to be assocd. with pancreatic cancer. Differential expression of some identified proteins was further confirmed by Western blotting anal. and/or immunohistochem. anal. Comparative proteomic anal. using 2-DE and MALDI-TOF-MS is an effective method for identifying differentially expressed proteins that may be the potential diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic targets for pancreatic cancer.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXlt1Ghtbk%253D&md5=fa36d1a413dfcacccde4b591abbdd13d

      Lu, H.; Chen, I.; Shimoda, L. A.; Park, Y.; Zhang, C.; Tran, L.; Zhang, H.; Semenza, G. L. Chemotherapy-induced Ca2+ release stimulates breast cancer stem cell enrichment. Cell Rep. 2017, 18, 1946– 1957,  DOI: 10.1016/j.celrep.2017.02.001
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Chemotherapy-Induced Ca2+ Release Stimulates Breast Cancer Stem Cell Enrichment
      Lu, Haiquan; Chen, Ivan; Shimoda, Larissa A.; Park, Youngrok; Zhang, Chuanzhao; Tran, Linh; Zhang, Huimin; Semenza, Gregg L.
      Cell Reports (2017), 18 (8), 1946-1957CODEN: CREED8; ISSN:2211-1247. (Cell Press)
      Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) play a crit. role in tumor recurrence and metastasis. Exposure of breast cancer cells to chemotherapy leads to an enrichment of BCSCs. Here, we find that chemotherapy induces the expression of glutathione S-transferase omega 1 (GSTO1), which is dependent on hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) and HIF-2. Knockdown of GSTO1 expression abrogates carboplatin-induced BCSC enrichment, decreases tumor initiation and metastatic capacity, and delays tumor recurrence after chemotherapy. GSTO1 interacts with the ryanodine receptor RYR1 and promotes calcium release from the endoplasmic reticulum. Increased cytosolic calcium levels activate PYK2 → SRC → STAT3 signaling, leading to increased expression of pluripotency factors and BCSC enrichment. HIF inhibition blocks chemotherapy-induced GSTO1 expression and BCSC enrichment. Combining HIF inhibitors with chemotherapy may improve clin. outcome in breast cancer.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXjtlGrs7s%253D&md5=e777b7e5c89919d0e3ed9100b86bf34d

      Lombardi, S.; Fuoco, I.; di Fluri, G.; Costa, F.; Ricchiuti, A.; Biondi, G.; Nardini, V.; Scarpato, R. Genomic instability and cellular stress in organ biopsies and peripheral blood lymphocytes from patients with colorectal cancer and predisposing pathologies. Oncotarget 2015, 6, 14852– 14864,  DOI: 10.18632/oncotarget.4032
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Genomic instability and cellular stress in organ biopsies and peripheral blood lymphocytes from patients with colorectal cancer and predisposing pathologies
      Lombardi Sara; Fuoco Ilenia; Scarpato Roberto; Lombardi Sara; Fuoco Ilenia; Scarpato Roberto; di Fluri Giorgia; Costa Francesco; Ricchiuti Angelo; Biondi Graziano; Nardini Vincenzo
      Oncotarget (2015), 6 (17), 14852-64 ISSN:.
      Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and polyps, are common colorectal pathologies in western society and are risk factors for development of colorectal cancer (CRC). Genomic instability is a cancer hallmark and is connected to changes in chromosomal structure, often caused by double strand break formation (DSB), and aneuploidy. Cellular stress, may contribute to genomic instability. In colorectal biopsies and peripheral blood lymphocytes of patients with IBD, polyps and CRC, we evaluated 1) genomic instability using the γH2AX assay as marker of DSB and micronuclei in mononuclear lymphocytes kept under cytodieresis inhibition, and 2) cellular stress through expression and cellular localization of glutathione-S-transferase omega 1 (GSTO1). Colon biopsies showed γH2AX increase starting from polyps, while lymphocytes already from IBD. Micronuclei frequency began to rise in lymphocytes of subjects with polyps, suggesting a systemic genomic instability condition. Colorectal tissues lost GSTO1 expression but increased nuclear localization with pathology progression. Lymphocytes did not change GSTO1 expression and localization until CRC formation, where enzyme expression was increased. We propose that the growing genomic instability found in our patients is connected with the alteration of cellular environment. Evaluation of genomic damage and cellular stress in colorectal pathologies may facilitate prevention and management of CRC.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2Mbgs1Shtw%253D%253D&md5=dad25e3f1e57c57d214713262c969c83

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Integrated phenotypic screening and activity-based protein profiling to reveal potential therapy targets of pancreatic cancer
      Liu, Wenyan; Zhang, Zhang; Zhang, Zhi-Min; Hao, Piliang; Ding, Ke; Li, Zhengqiu
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2019), 55 (11), 1596-1599CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Pancreatic cancer has been defined as one of the most complex and challenging cancers to treat, but very few valid therapeutic targets have been identified to date. To address this issue, a 61-compd. library was readily created by Ugi reaction followed by phenotypic screening, leading to the discovery of two most potent inhibitors, P21 (I) and P26(II), which significantly impair BxPC-3 pancreatic cancer cell survival. A series of interacting protein hits, such as GSTO1, FAM213A, RAB6A/6B/39A and USMG5, were subsequently identified by quant. chemoproteomics studies. The main cellular target, GSTO1, was further validated as a novel pancreatic cancer therapeutic target.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Identification of Platinum-Resistance Associated Proteins through Proteomic Analysis of Human Ovarian Cancer Cells and Their Platinum-Resistant Sublines
      Yan, Xue-dong; Pan, Ling-ya; Yuan, Ye; Lang, Jing-he; Mao, Ning
      Journal of Proteome Research (2007), 6 (2), 772-780CODEN: JPROBS; ISSN:1535-3893. (American Chemical Society)
      Chemoresistance is a major therapeutic obstacle in cancer patients, and the mechanisms of drug resistance are not fully understood. In the present study, the authors established platinum-resistant human ovarian cancer cell lines and identified differentially expressed proteins related to platinum resistance. The total proteins of two sensitive (SKOV3 and A2780) and four resistant (SKOV3/CDDP, SKOV3/CBP, A2780/CDDP, and A2780/CBP) human ovarian cancer cell lines were isolated by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE). The differentially expressed proteins were identified using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In total, 57 differential protein spots were identified, and five proteins, including annexin A3, destrin, cofilin 1, glutathione-S-transferase omega 1, and cytosolic NADP+-dependent isocitrate dehydrogenase, were found to be coinstantaneous significance compared with their parental cells. The expression of the five proteins was validated by quant. PCR and Western blot, and the Western blot results showed complete consistency with proteomic techniques. The five proteins are hopeful to become candidates for platinum resistance. These may be useful for further study of resistance mechanisms and screening of resistant biomarkers.

      Piaggi, S.; Raggi, C.; Corti, A.; Pitzalis, E.; Mascherpa, M. C.; Saviozzi, M.; Pompella, A.; Casini, A. F. Glutathione transferase omega 1-1 (GSTO1-1) plays an anti-apoptotic role in cell resistance to cisplatin toxicity. Carcinogenesis 2010, 31, 804– 811,  DOI: 10.1093/carcin/bgq031
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Glutathione transferase omega 1-1 (GSTO1-1) plays an anti-apoptotic role in cell resistance to cisplatin toxicity
      Piaggi, Simona; Raggi, Chiara; Corti, Alessandro; Pitzalis, Emanuela; Mascherpa, Marco C.; Saviozzi, Michela; Pompella, Alfonso; Casini, Alessandro F.
      Carcinogenesis (2010), 31 (5), 804-811CODEN: CRNGDP; ISSN:0143-3334. (Oxford University Press)
      Several lines of evidence correlate the overexpression of glutathione S-transferase omega 1-1 (GSTO1-1) with the onset of drug resistance of cancer cells; however, no direct evidence is yet available. In order to investigate the mechanisms involved, stable transfection with GSTO1-1 complementary DNA was performed in HeLa cells, which spontaneously express very low levels of GSTO1-1. When transfected cells were seeded at low d., a sharp increase in GSTO1-1 expression was obsd. as compared with controls, along with an increased resistance against cisplatin cytotoxicity. When seeded at increasing densities, control untransfected cells also presented with an increase in GSTO1-1 expression, again accompanied by cisplatin resistance; the latter was significantly reduced after transfection with GSTO1-1 small interfering RNA. Cisplatin resistance of transfected cells was not accounted for by changes in the intracellular drug concn. nor in the amt. of DNA cross-links or content of glutathione. Rather, transfected cells presented with a marked decrease of apoptosis as compared with controls, suggesting that GSTO1-1 overexpression may prevent cisplatin toxicity by interfering with the apoptotic process. Cisplatin treatment was in fact followed at early times (1-2 h) by activation of both Akt kinase and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK)-1/2 in the transfected cells but not in controls. Conversely, in transfected cells, the strong activation of Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK)-1 induced by cisplatin at later times (10-20 h) was completely prevented. In conclusion, GSTO1-1 overexpression appears to be assocd. with activation of survival pathways (Akt and ERK1/2) and inhibition of apoptotic pathways (JNK1), as well as protection against cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXlvVWjsbo%253D&md5=0856d5d696594a33977e2c04d1a3adc8
    19. 19
      Pljesa-Ercegovac, M.; Savic-Radojevic, A.; Matic, M.; Coric, V.; Djukic, T.; Radic, T.; Simic, T. Glutathione transferases: potential targets to overcome chemoresistance in solid tumors. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2018, 19, 3785  DOI: 10.3390/ijms19123785
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Glutathione transferases: potential targets to overcome chemoresistance in solid tumors
      Pljesa-Ercegovac, Marija; Savic-Radojevic, Ana; Matic, Marija; Coric, Vesna; Djukic, Tatjana; Radic, Tanja; Simic, Tatjana
      International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2018), 19 (12), 3785/1-3785/21CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
      A review. Multifunctional enzymes glutathione transferases (GSTs) are involved in the development of chemoresistance, thus representing a promising target for a novel approach in cancer treatment. This superfamily of polymorphic enzymes exhibits extraordinary substrate promiscuity responsible for detoxification of numerous conventional chemotherapeutics, at the same time regulating signaling pathways involved in cell proliferation and apoptosis. In addn. to upregulated GST expression, different cancer cell types have a unique GST signature, enabling targeted selectivity for isoenzyme specific inhibitors and pro-drugs. As a result of extensive research, certain GST inhibitors are already tested in clin. trials. Catalytic properties of GST isoenzymes are also exploited in bio-activation of specific pro-drugs, enabling their targeted accumulation in cancer cells with upregulated expression of the appropriate GST isoenzyme. Moreover, the latest approach to increase specificity in treatment of solid tumors is development of GST pro-drugs that are derivs. of conventional anti-cancer drugs. A future perspective is based on the design of new drugs, which would selectively target GST overexpressing cancers more prone to developing chemoresistance, while decreasing side effects in off-target cells.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXot1Kgsbw%253D&md5=02d842d5f1b2b7bc5f84f9684bc77d95
